If the dog has inflicted a bite on any person, or another animal, within the last ten days, the owner of the dog shall report such fact to the veterinarian, and no rabies vaccine shall be administered until after the ten-day observation period. 
(Code 1969, § 6-31; Ord. No. 90-31, § 2.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-50. - Certificate of vaccination. 
    Upon vaccination, the veterinarian shall execute and furnish to the owner of the dog as evidence thereof, a certificate upon a form furnished by the veterinarian. The veterinarian shall retain a duplicate copy. Such certificate shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the vaccinated dog; 
(2)  The date of vaccination; 
(3)  The year and number of rabies tag; and 
(4)  The breed, age, color and sex of the vaccinated dog. 
(Code 1969, § 6-32; Ord. No. 90-31, § 2.2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-51. - Rabies tag. 
    Concurrent with the issuance and delivery of the certificate of vaccination referred to in section 22-50, the owner of the dog shall cause to be attached to the collar or harness of the vaccinated dog a metal tag, serially numbered to correspond with the vaccination certificate number, and bearing the year of issuance and the name of the issuing veterinarian and his address. The owner shall cause the collar or harness, with the attached metal tag, to be worn by his dog at all times. 
(Code 1969, § 6-33; Ord. No. 90-31, § 2.3, 12-18-1990) 
Secs. 22-52, 22-53. - Reserved. 
Sec. 22-54. - Harboring unvaccinated animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor any domestic animal which has not been vaccinated against rabies, as provided in section 22-49 or which cannot be identified as having a current vaccination certificate. 
(Code 1969, § 6-36; Ord. No. 90-31, § 2.6, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-55. - Animal exposed to rabies. 
    Any person having knowledge of the existence of any animal known to have been, or suspected of being, exposed to rabies must immediately report such knowledge to the local health authority, giving any information which may be required. For any animal known to have been, or suspected of being, exposed to rabies, the following rules must apply: 
(1)  Animals having a current vaccination must be revaccinated immediately and confined according to the method prescribed by the local health authority for a period of not less than 45 days. 
(2)  Animals not having a current vaccination should be humanely destroyed. However, if the owner of such an animal elects, he may, at his expense and in a manner prescribed by the local health authority, confine the animal. Such animal must be vaccinated immediately following exposure and quarantined for not less than 90 days, and given booster vaccinations during the third and eighth weeks of isolation. 
(3)  These provisions apply only to domestic animals for which an approved rabies vaccine is available. 
(4)  In situations where none of the requirements of this section are applicable, the recommendations contained in the latest edition of the publication titled The Compendium of Animal Rabies Control, published by the National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians, should be followed. 
(Code 1969, § 6-37; Ord. No. 90-31, § 2.7, 12-18-1990) 
State Law reference- Disposition of domestic animals exposed to rabies, 25 Tex. Admin. Code § 169.30. 
Sec. 22-56. - Animal bites; reporting, quarantine, investigation, exclusions. 
(a)  Report to health authority. Any person having knowledge of an animal bite to a human will report the incident to the local health authority as soon as possible, but not later than 24 hours from the time of the incident. 
(b)  Quarantine of animal. The owner of the biting animal will place that animal in quarantine, as prescribed in section 22-57, under the supervision of the local health authority. 
(c)  Investigation. The local health authority will investigate each bite incident, utilizing standardized reporting forms provided by the state department of health. 
(d)  Exclusions. Bites to humans from rodents, rabbits, birds, and reptiles are excluded from the reporting requirements of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 6-38; Ord. No. 90-31, § 3, 12-18-1990) 
State Law reference- Quarantine method and testing, 25 Tex. Admin. Code § 169.27. 
Sec. 22-57. - Quarantine procedures; observation. 
    When an animal which has bitten a human has been identified, the owner will be required to produce the animal for ten days' confinement at the owner's expense. Refusal to produce such animal constitutes a violation of this section and each day of such refusal constitutes a separate and individual violation. The ten-day observation period will begin on the day of the bite incident. The animal must be placed in the animal control facilities specified for this purpose, if available. However, the owner of the animal may request permission from the local health authority for home quarantine if the following criteria can be met: 
(1)  Secure facilities must be available at the home of the animal's owner, and must be approved by the local health authority; 
(2)  The animal is currently vaccinated against rabies; 
(3)  The local health authority or a licensed veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first and last days of the quarantine period. If the animal becomes ill during the observation period, the local health authority must be notified by the person having possession of the animal. At the end of the observation period the release from quarantine must be accomplished in writing; 
(4)  The animal was not in violation of any laws at the time of the bite; 
(5)  If the biting animal cannot be maintained in secure quarantine, it shall be humanely destroyed and the brain submitted to a state department of health certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis; and 
(6)  If for any reason the animal dies during the quarantine, the brain must be submitted to a state department of health certified laboratory. 
(Code 1969, § 6-39; Ord. No. 90-31, § 4.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-58. - No interruption of observation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interrupt the ten-day observation period. 
(Code 1969, § 6-40; Ord. No. 90-31, § 4.2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-59. - Wild animals not quarantined. 
    No wild animal will be placed in quarantine. All wild animals involved in biting incidents will be humanely killed in such a manner that the brain is not mutilated. The brain shall be submitted to a state department of health certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis. 
(Code 1969, § 6-41; Ord. No. 90-31, § 4.3, 12-18-1990) 
Secs. 22-60-22-76. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGISTRATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Registration of dogs and cats, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.031 et seq. 

Sec. 22-77. - Required. 
    No owner shall have within the city any dog six months of age or older unless such dog is currently registered with the local health authority. A current metal registration certificate issued by the local health authority, or a veterinarian authorized by the local health authority to issue the certificate, must be affixed to a collar or harness that must be worn by the dog at all times. No dog shall be registered until it has a current vaccination. 
(Code 1969, § 6-51; Ord. No. 90-31, § 5.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-78. - Procedures and fees. 
(a)  Registration procedures and fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Application for initial issuance or renewal of each registration must be made by the owner, in writing or in person, and be accompanied by a fee of $5.00, unless the dog being registered has been neutered or spayed and proof of such surgical sterilization can be shown to an animal control officer or a veterinarian authorized to issue such registration; then the fee will be $2.00. Dogs under the age of one year shall be registered at the sterilized fee. Animals may be exempted from this sterilization provision upon written recommendation from a veterinarian that such alteration would be harmful or dangerous to the animal. 
(2)  Registration certificates shall be renewed annually. The registration period will be from January 1 to December 31. Certificates for the new period shall be available for sale at least 30 days in advance, and 60 days following January 1 and shall constitute a valid registration upon issuance. 
(3)  Registration and/or vaccination certificates (and tags) shall be valid only for the animal for which it was originally issued. 
(4)  If there is a change in ownership of a registered dog, the new owner shall have the registration transferred to his name. Application for such transfer shall be made to the animal control officer in writing or in person. 
(5)  Fee-exempt registrations may be issued for the following: 
a.  Dogs trained to assist the auditorial or visually impaired person; 
b.  Animals owned by a nonresident whose stay in the city will not exceed 30 days, and provided the owner keeps his animal confined at all times while in the city and can show adequate proof of vaccination for rabies; 
c.  Animals brought in by transients for exhibition or as household pets in conjunction with a circus or carnival, provided that the owner of such animals shall declare each animal and shall show proof of vaccination upon request of the local health authority or its representative; and 
d.  Any dog owned by any law enforcement agency which is headquartered within the United States of America. 
(b)  Eligibility for fee-exempt registration does not relieve the owner of his responsibility under other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 6-52; Ord. No. 90-31, § 5.2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-79. - Reserved. 
Sec. 22-80. - Guard dog. 
(a)  Every person having care, control, or custody of any dog which has received guard dog training must register such dog with the local health authority. Any dog which has received guard dog training may be destroyed when such dog is found running at large. The owners or keepers of guard dogs shall be subject to the other provisions of this section. An ID collar identifying the dog as a guard dog must be worn at all times and the dog must wear a muzzle when out of confinement. The registration form shall have: 
(1)  The business name, address and telephone number of the commercial property where guard a dog is to be used; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the dog's handler who can be reached at any time during the day or night; 
(3)  The number of dogs to be used and a general description of their use; 
(4)  The location where dogs are to be housed; and 
(5)  Any other information that the animal control officer deems necessary by rule or regulation. Permit holders shall notify the animal control officer if any information recorded as part of the permit application is changed during the course of the period for which the permit is issued. 
(b)  Dogs which are used to protect the property of their owner's private residence shall be excluded from the provisions of this section unless the residence is located on premises utilized for commercial purposes. 
(Code 1969, § 6-54; Ord. No. 90-31, § 5.4, 12-18-1990) 
Secs. 22-81-22-103. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - NUISANCES 

Sec. 22-104. - Enumeration of animal nuisances. 
    The following conditions or acts are classified and declared to be a public nuisance and allowing such conditions to exist or to be continued is prohibited: 
(1)  Barking and other noises. The keeping or harboring of any animal, which, by causing frequent or long continued barking, cry or noise, shall disturb any person of ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity; 
(2)  Foul, offensive odors. The keeping or harboring of any animal in such a manner as to endanger the public health; to annoy neighbors by the accumulation of animal wastes which cause foul and offensive odors, or are considered to be a hazard to any other animal or human being; or by continued presence on the premises of another; 
(3)  Pens, stables, enclosures. The keeping or harboring of any animal pens, stables, or enclosures in which any animal may be kept or confined which, from use, has become offensive to a person of ordinary sensibilities; 
(4)  Keeping, harboring bees. The keeping or harboring of bees in such a manner as to deny the lawful use of adjacent property or as to endanger personal health and welfare; 
(5)  Disturbances by cats. Persistent laxless in supervision of cats so that their running at large results in disturbance to persons of ordinary sensibilities; 
(6)  Animals on school grounds. The keeping or harboring of any animal which trespasses on school grounds; 
(7)  Animals at large. The keeping or harboring of any animal which is repeatedly at large; 
(8)  Animals causing damage to property. The keeping or harboring of any animal which damages private or public property; 
(9)  Barking, howling at unreasonable hour. The keeping or harboring of any animal which barks; whines, howls or makes other annoying noises in an excessive, continuous or unreasonable fashion at an unreasonable hour; or 
(10)  Defecation on public property. The keeping or harboring of any animal which defecates on public or private property. 
(Code 1969, § 6-61; Ord. No. 90-31, § 7.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-105. - Dumping of animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or dump an animal within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 6-62; Ord. No. 90-31, § 7.2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-106. - Removal of excreta. 
    The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by the animal on public property, walks, recreation areas or the property of others. 
(Code 1969, § 6-63; Ord. No. 90-31, § 7.3, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-107. - Limitation on number of dogs housed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, house, keep, board, or have more than three dogs more than four months of age at any one residence within the city, unless such residence is more than 150 feet from any other residence, or unless such dogs are so housed, fenced, controlled and kept as to create no disturbance to the neighborhood. 
(Code 1969, § 6-64; Ord. No. 90-31, § 7.4, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-108. - Poisonous, dangerous animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any poisonous reptile or dangerous animal within the city. 
(Code 1969, § 6-65; Ord. No. 90-31, § 7.5, 12-18-1990) 
Secs. 22-109-22-129. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VICIOUS ANIMALS 

Sec. 22-130. - Running at large. 
    Any vicious animal found running at large may be destroyed by any peace officer in the interest of public safety or tranquilized by the local health authority personnel. 
(Code 1969, § 6-71; Ord. No. 90-31, § 9.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-131. - Removal. 
    The local health authority may order any owner or person having care, control, or custody of any vicious animal to take such animal permanently from the city. Such animal must be removed immediately following receipt of such an order, even if an appeal is initiated. This order may be appealed in writing within ten days to the city manager. The city manager may uphold, reverse or modify the animal as a condition to allowing the animal to remain in the city. If the city manager upholds the animal control officer's order, the owner or person having care, control, or custody shall not bring the animal back inside the city limits. 
(Code 1969, § 6-72; Ord. No. 90-31, § 9.2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-132. - Offense. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person owns or keeps in his custody or control a dog that he knows has engaged in vicious conduct and the person does not: 
(1)  Restrain the dog at all times on a leash or similar device in the immediate control of the owner or other person at the direction of the owner or in a pen or other enclosure reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the pen or enclosure on its own; and 
(2)  Have insurance coverage in an amount of at least $100,000.00 insuring against liability of the person for damages resulting from bodily injury to an individual caused by any dog belonging to or in the custody or control of the person. 
(b)  A person has 15 days from the date on which the person knows his dog has engaged in vicious conduct to obtain insurance coverage. 
(Code 1969, § 6-73; Ord. No. 90-31, § 9.3, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-133. - Failure to remove. 
    If the owner or person having care, custody or control of a vicious animal fails to remove such animal as provided for in sections 22-130 and 22-131, such animal may be impounded and/or destroyed. 
(Code 1969, § 6-74; Ord. No. 90-31, § 9.4, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-134. - Report of removal; offense. 
    The owner or person having care, custody or control of a vicious animal must report the disposition and relocation of such animal to the animal control officer, in writing, within ten days after the expiration date for removal of such animal from the city. Each day thereafter that such information is not provided shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 6-75; Ord. No. 90-31, § 9.5, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-135. - Search and seizure. 
    The local health authority shall be authorized to obtain a search and seizure warrant if there is reason to believe that an animal ordered removed from the city for being vicious has not been so removed. 
(Code 1969, § 6-76; Ord. No. 90-31, § 9.6, 12-18-1990) 
Secs. 22-136-22-153. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 22-154. - Animals that may be impounded. 
    The following animals may be impounded: 
(1)  Dogs not exhibiting evidence of being vaccinated as described in section 22-49 et seq., or registered as described in division 3 of this article; 
(2)  Any animal infected or kept under conditions which could endanger the public or animal health; 
(3)  Any animal that creates a nuisance, as defined in division 4 of this article; 
(4)  Any animal running at large, as stated in division 5 of this article; 
(5)  Any animal treated in a manner determined by the animal control officer to be cruel or inhumane; 
(6)  Any animal that has bitten a human being or needs to be placed under observation for rabies determination, as determined by the local health authority; and 
(7)  Any animal violating any provision of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 6-81; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-155. - Right of owner or occupant of premises to detain animal. 
    If any of the animals named in this article are found upon the premises of any person, the owner or occupant of the premises shall have the right to confine such animal in a humane manner until he can notify the animal control officer to come and impound such animal. When so notified, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to have such animal impounded as herein provided. 
(Code 1969, § 6-82; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-156. - Effort to contact owner. 
    Reasonable effort shall be made by the animal control officer to contact the owner of any animal impounded which is wearing a current vaccination tag; however, final responsibility for location of an impounded animal is that of the owner. 
(Code 1969, § 6-83; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.3, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-157. - Release of impounded animal to owner. 
    The owner can resume possession of any impounded animal upon payment of impoundment fees, handling fees, and any veterinary bills incurred by the local health authority for the welfare of the animal, and upon compliance with the vaccination and registration provisions of this Code, except where prohibited in sections 22-158 and 22-159. 
(Code 1969, § 6-84; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.4, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-158. - Court jurisdiction. 
    Disposition of animals impounded on the grounds of cruel or inhumane treatment shall be determined by the court having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1969, § 6-85; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.5, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-159. - Expiration of quarantine prerequisite to release. 
    If any animal is being held under quarantine or observation for rabies, the owner shall not be entitled possession until it has been released from quarantine. 
(Code 1969, § 6-86; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.6, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-160. - Location and establishment of pound. 
    The City Commission shall select and establish a place for impounding all animals impounded under any provision of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 6-87; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.7, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-161. - Duration of impoundment before disposition. 
    Any animal, except vicious or wild animals, not reclaimed by the owner may be humanely euthanized after being impounded for 72 hours, except that any animal wearing a current registration tag shall be impounded for six days. 
(Code 1969, § 6-88; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.8, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-162. - Immediate disposition of wild or vicious animals. 
    Any impounded vicious or wild animal, unless there is reason to believe that it has an owner, may be immediately disposed of as may be deemed appropriate by the animal control officer. 
(Code 1969, § 6-89; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.9, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-163. - Immediate disposition of certain dependent baby animals. 
    Any nursing baby animal impounded without the mother, or where the mother cannot or refuses to provide nutritious milk, may be immediately euthanized to prevent further suffering. 
(Code 1969, § 6-90; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.10, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-164. - Waiver for immediate disposition. 
    An owner who no longer wishes responsibility for an animal, or believes the animal to be in an ill or injured condition, may sign a written waiver supplied by the animal control officer or the local health authority allowing the animal to be immediately euthanized in a humane manner, provided that no dog or cat that has bitten a human being shall be euthanized before the expiration of the ten-day quarantine period. 
(Code 1969, § 6-91; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.11, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-165. - Disposition of suffering animal. 
    Any impounded animal that appears to be suffering from extreme injury or illness may be euthanized or given to a nonprofit humane organization for the purpose of veterinary medical care, as determined by the animal control officer or the local health authority. 
(Code 1969, § 6-92; Ord. No. 90-31, § 10.12, 12-18-1990) 
Secs. 22-166-22-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY 

Sec. 22-186. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
    Enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the animal control officer, the local health authority, and the city police department. 
(Code 1969, § 6-101; Ord. No. 90-31, § 12.1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 22-187. - Issuance of citations. 
    When any animal or the owner or keeper of any animal is found in violation of any provision of this article, the local health authority, the animal control officer, any officer of the city police department, or any employee of the city health department shall have the authority to issue citations which shall require the owner of such animal to appear in municipal court within ten days to answer a charge of violation of this article. Notice of the court date shall be noted on the citation. 
(1)  Signing of the citation by the owner shall only be a promise to appear and is not an admission of guilt. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to fail to appear in municipal court on the date noted on the citation. 
(3)  Should the owner fail or refuse to sign the citation, the local health authority, or the animal control officer shall file a complaint against such owner in a municipal court. 
(4)  If the person being cited is not present, the local health authority or the animal control officer may send the citation to the alleged offender by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(Code 1969, § 6-102; Ord. No. 90-31, § 12.2, 12-18-1990) 
DIVISION 8. - ANIMAL SHELTER 

Sec. 22-188. - Advisory committee. 
    There is hereby established an animal shelter advisory committee composed of one veterinarian, one City of Weslaco official, one person whose duties include the daily operation of an animal shelter and one representative from an animal welfare organization and one citizen of the City of Weslaco. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § I, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 22-189. - Duties. 
    The animal shelter advisory committee shall assist the City of Weslaco in complying with the requirements of V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code Chapter 823. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § I, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 22-190. - Meetings. 
    The animal shelter committee shall meet at least three times in a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § I, 1-17-2012) 
Secs. 22-191-22-214. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Registration of dogs and cats, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.031 et seq. 

Sec. 22-215. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Livestock means and includes cattle, horses, mules, jacks, jennets, hogs, sheep, goats, rabbits, and guinea pigs. 
    Poultry means and includes chickens, turkeys, guineas, geese, ducks, and pigeons. 
(Code 1969, § 6-111; Ord. No. 183, § 1, 4-18-1950) 
Sec. 22-216. - Not to be kept in city limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, or cause to be kept, any poultry or livestock within the area defined in chapter 150 as the central business district. secondary and highway business district or neighborhood business district as the same exist now, or as they may hereafter exist. 
(Code 1969, § 6-112; Ord. No. 183, § 2, 4-18-1950) 
Sec. 22-217. - Poultry and livestock prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or cause to be kept any poultry or livestock within the city as authorized in an R-3 zoning district except as authorized in chapter 150. 
(Code 1969, § 6-113; Ord. No. 183, § 2, 4-18-1950) 
Secs. 22-218-22-220. - Reserved. 
Sec. 22-221. - Red-crowned parrots, yellow-headed parrots, red-lourde parrots, and green parakeets. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Green parakeet means a bird classified scientifically as the Aratange Holochlora. 
    Red-crowned parrot means a bird classified scientifically as the Amazona Viridigenalis. 
    Red-lourde parrot means a bird classified scientifically as the Amazona Autumnalis. 
    Wildlife habitat means any tree or shrub used for food or nesting by the red-crowned parrot, the yellow-headed parrot, and the green parakeet. 
    Yellow-headed parrot means a bird classified scientifically as the Amazona Oratrix. 
(b)  Unlawful to injure or capture. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city limits to knowingly or intentionally to injure, capture, or kill a red-crowned parrot, yellow-headed parrot, red-lourde parrot or green parakeet. 
(c)  Unlawful to remove from nest or destroy eggs. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city limits to knowingly or intentionally in the wild habitat remove young red-crowned parrots, yellow-headed parrots, red-lourde parrots and green parakeets from a nest or in any manner take, remove, or destroy any eggs of the red-crowned parrot, yellow-headed parrot, red-lourde parrot and green parakeet. 
(d)  Unlawful to cut down tree with nest. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally cut down or in any other way harm a tree in which there exists a nest of the red-crowned parrot, yellow-headed parrot, red-lourde parrot or green parakeet, within the city limits. 
(Code 1969, § 6-117; Ord. No. 99-14, § 1, 9-7-1999) 
State Law reference- Treatment of live birds, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.003. 
Chapter 26 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of housing and other structures, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.001 et seq.; national electrical code applicable statewide for residential construction, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.214. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Permit fees accounts. 
(a)  Established. The building official is hereby authorized to establish permit fee accounts and to issue building, mechanical, electrical, plumbing, gas, housing, swimming pool, and other such permits as are within such official's power to issue, charging the permit fee to the account of the contractor or other persons applying for same. 
(b)  Additional fee to cover costs. The city shall be entitled to charge, in addition to other charges, a fee of $5.00 per month to cover the cost of administration and handling of any such account maintained by the building official. 
(c)  Due date; delinquency. Any statement for permit fees shall be due on the 15th day of the month next following the month in which such statement is mailed; and any statement remaining unpaid after such date shall be considered delinquent. 
(d)  Permits not issued to delinquent accounts. No person or contractor having a delinquent permit fee account shall be issued any type of permit by the city until such time as such permit fee account is paid. 
(Code 1969, § 8-1; Ord. No. 82-14, §§ 1-4, 2-2-1982) 
Sec. 26-2. - ICC/AWSI A117.1 (A.D.A.) Code. 
    The ICC/AWSI A117.1 Code, 1998 edition (known as the A.D.A. Code) is hereby adopted as the A.D.A. Code of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 8-2; Ord. No. 2002-14, § I, 9-3-2002) 
Sec. 26-3. - International Energy Conservation Code. 
(a)  Adopted by reference. A certain document is on file in the office of the Building Official and the City of Weslaco, being marked and designated as the International Energy Conservation Code, 2015 edition, including Appendix A as published and attached by the International Code Council, Inc., be and is hereby adopted as the Energy Conservation Code of the City of Weslaco, in the State of Texas, for regulating and governing energy efficient building envelopes and installation of energy efficient mechanical, lighting and power systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Energy Conservation Code, 2015 edition, on file in the office of the Building Official are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Revision. The following sections are hereby revised: 
(1)  Section C101.1 and Section R101.1: City of Weslaco. 
(2)  Section 104.5. Approved inspection agencies: The Building Official is authorized to accept reports of approved inspection agencies, provided such agencies satisfy the requirements as qualifications and reliability. 
(3)  Section 104.5.1. Approved agents: Only those third party inspectors who have been registered with the City and have met the requirements of the Building Official shall be accepted as approved energy conservation code compliance inspectors. A list of third party inspectors that are registered with the City to be third party energy compliance inspectors will be available on the City's Development Services website for public viewing. 
(4)  Section 104.5.2. Requirements for registered third party inspectors: 
a)  Insurance - Third party inspectors are required to have five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) of commercial general liability, with a combined single limit per occurrence provided coverage for property damage and bodily injury. 
b)  Registration - All third party inspectors are required to register with the City for participation in the City of Weslaco Energy Conservation Code Compliance Program. 
c)  Renewal - All third party inspectors are required to submit an annual renewal and proof of current insurance to Development Services. 
(5)  Section 104.8. Approval: After the prescribed tests and inspections indicate that the work complies in all respects with this code, a notice of approval shall be issued by the Building Official. 
(6)  Section 104.8.a. Method of Approval: Test results will be accepted by Development Services via electronic submission. 
(7)  Section 104.8.b. Documentation Requirements for Code Compliance Registration with the City shall contain: 
1.  The name of the company. 
2.  Company address. 
3.  Specific energy improvements offered by company. 
4.  Name of registered technician that will be performing the inspection. 
5.  Type of certification that inspector has acquired. Certified HERS Raters or Rating Field Inspectors by RESNET, Performance Verification Technicians certified by Texas HERO, or other certifications that are approved by the Building Official. 
6.  Certificate of Insurance. 
(8)  Section 104.8.c. Documentation Requirements for Inspection Submission: 
1.  Verification of third party registration. 
2.  Disclosure of inspection results. 
3.  Pass or fail results. 
(9)  Section 104.8.d. Time Frame for Submitting Approved Test Results: Test results by a third party inspector in compliance with Section 104.5.1 shall be filed with Development Services, Building Division, prior to the Certificate of Occupancy being issued. 
(10)  Section 104.8.1. Revocation: The Building Official is authorized to, in writing, suspend or revoke a notice of approval whenever the certificate is issued in error, incorrect information was supplied, or where it is determined that the building, structure, premise, or portion thereof is in violation of any ordinance or regulation or any of the provisions of this code. 
(11)  Section 108.4.1. Violations penalties: Any person who violates a provision of this code, fails to complies with an of the requirements thereof, or erects, installs, alters, or repairs work in violation of the approved construction documents, directive of the building official, or a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a Class C Misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more, two thousand dollars ($2,000). Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(12)  Section 108.4.2. Stop work orders. Upon notice from the building official that work is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, the owner's agent, or the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to given written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(13)  Amending Section 302.1 C. Interior design conditions: The interior design temperatures used for heating and cooling load calculations shall be a maximum of 72° F (22° C) for heating and minimum of 72° F (22° C) for cooling. 
(14)  Amending Section 403.3. Economizers to add exception number 10. Interior air handling units. 
(Ord. No. 2006-17, § 2, 8-1-2006; Ord. No. 2011-10, § 1, 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2013-13, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 2017-10, §§ 1, 2, 5-2-2017) 
State Law reference- Home rule municipality may require buildings to comply with energy conservation standards, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.901. 
Secs. 26-4-26-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE LIMITS 

Sec. 26-25. - First fire zone. 
    The first fire zone of the city is hereby established as follows: 
    The first fire zone shall hereafter be that area within the city beginning at the intersection of the south curbline of Third Street and the west curbline of Illinois Avenue; thence south along the curbline of Illinois Avenue to the intersection with the north curbline of Fourth Street; thence west along the north curbline of Fourth Street to the centerline of the alley existing between Illinois and Kansas Avenues; thence south along the centerline of said alley to the point of intersection thereof with the north curbline of Sixth Street for the southeast corner of this zone; thence west along the north curbline of Sixth Street to the point of intersection thereof with the centerline of the alley existing between Missouri and Nebraska Avenues for the southwest corner of this zone; thence north along the centerline of said alley to the point of intersection with the north curbline of Third street for an inside corner; thence west along the north curbline of Third Street to the point of intersection thereof with the east curbline of Nebraska Avenue; thence north along the east curbline of Nebraska Avenue to the point of intersection thereof with the south curbline of U.S. Highway 83 (Business) continuing northerly in a straight line across U. S. 83 (Business) to the intersection of the east curbline of Cedro and Railroad Streets; thence in an easterly direction with the north line of Railroad Street to the centerline of the alley existing between Missouri and Texas Boulevard; thence north along the centerline of said alley to the north curbline of Los Torritos Street; thence west along the north curbline of Los Torritos to the east curbline of Missouri; thence north along the east curbline of Missouri to an intersection with the north curbline of Esplanada Street; thence west along the north curbline of Esplanada to an intersection with the east curbline of Pino Avenue; thence north along the east curbline of Pino Avenue to an intersection with the south curbline of Pike Boulevard for the northwest corner of this zone; thence east along the south curbline of Pike Boulevard to an intersection with the west curbline of Kansas Avenue for the northeast corner of this zone; thence south along the west curbline of Kansas Avenue to an intersection with the north curbline of Casa Blanca Street; thence west along the north curbline of Casa Blanca Street to the intersection thereof with the west curbline of Outlet Street; thence south along the west curbline of Outlet Street to an intersection with the north curbline of Los Torritos Street; thence in a southern direction in a straight line to the point of intersection of the south curbline of Los Torritos Street with the centerline of the alley existing between Kansas Avenue and Texas Boulevard; thence south along the centerline of said alley to the point of intersection thereof with the north right-of-way line of the Missouri-Pacific Railway Company; thence in a southeasterly direction along the north right-of-way line of said railroad to the point of intersection thereof with the west curbline of Illinois Avenue; thence south along the west curbline of Illinois Avenue across said railroad right-of-way and U. S. 83 Business Route to the point of intersection of the west curbline of Illinois Avenue with the south curbline of Third Street, being the point of beginning. 
(Code 1969, § 8-8; Ord. No. 69-9, § 1, 4-15-1969) 
Sec. 26-26. - Second fire zone. 
    The second fire zone of the city shall consist of an east part and a west part: 
    The east part of the second fire zone shall begin at the intersection of the centerline of the alley existing between Texas Boulevard and Kansas Avenue with the south curbline of Second Street; thence east along the south curbline of Second Street to the point of intersection thereof with the west line of Garza Avenue; thence south along the west curbline of Garza Avenue to the point of intersection thereof with the south curbline of Burns Street; thence east along the south curbline of Burns Street to the point of intersection with the west line of an unnamed street or avenue in a former drain ditch right-of-way existing along the west side of the James M. Black Subdivision; thence south along the west line of said unnamed street or avenue to an intersection with south curbline of Witmer Street; thence east with the south curbline of Witmer Street extended to an intersection with the west curbline of Utah Avenue; thence south along the west curbline of Utah Avenue to the point of intersection with the south curbline of Davenport Street extended; thence east along the south curbline of Davenport Street to an intersection with the west line of Airport Drive (Mile 4 West); thence south along the west line of Airport Drive to an intersection with the south curbline of U. S. Highway 83 (Business); thence along the south curbline of U. S. Highway 83 (Business) to the intersection thereof with the north curbline of sixth Street; thence westerly along the north curbline of Sixth Street to a point thereon 150 feet south of said south curbline of U. S. Highway 83 (Business); thence westerly along a line 150 feet south of and parallel with said south curbline of said U. S. Highway to the point of joinder of said line with the north curbline of Fourth Street; thence along the north curbline of Fourth Street to the point of intersection with the east curbline of Illinois Avenue; thence north along the east curbline of Illinois Avenue to the point of intersection thereof with the north right-of-way line of Missouri Pacific Railway; thence in a westerly direction along the north right-of-way line of said railroad to the point of intersection thereof with the centerline of the alley existing between Texas Boulevard and Kansas Avenue; thence north along the centerline of said alley to an intersection with the south curbline of Second Street, the place of beginning. 
    The west part of the second fire zone shall begin at the intersection of the west curbline of Nebraska Avenue with the north curbline of Third Street; thence west along the north curbline of Third Street to the east curbline of Oklahoma Avenue; thence on a straight line to a point in the east curbline of Border Avenue 300 feet south of the south curbline of U.S. Highway 83 (Business); thence north along the east curbline of Border Avenue to a point 450 feet north of the north curbline of U.S. 83 (Business); thence in an easterly direction in a straight line to the intersection of the west curbline of Republica Avenue with the south curbline of Hidalgo Street; thence along the south curbline of Hidalgo Street to the west curbline of Missouri Avenue; thence south along the west curbline of Missouri Avenue to the south curbline of Second Street; thence east along the south curbline of Second Street to the centerline of the alley existing between Texas Boulevard and Missouri Avenue; thence south along the centerline of said alley to the north right-of-way line of the Missouri-Pacific Railway; thence in a westerly direction along the north railway line of said railway to the west curbline of Cedro Avenue; thence in a southerly direction in a straight line to the point of intersection on the west curbline of Nebraska Avenue with the south curbline of U.S. Highway 83 (Business); thence easterly along the south curbline of U.S. 83 (Business) to the west curbline of Nebraska Avenue; thence south along the west curbline of Nebraska Avenue to the point of intersection with the north curbline of Third Street, the point of beginning. 
(Code 1969, § 8-9; Ord. No. 69-9, § 2, 4-15-1969) 
Sec. 26-27. - Fire zone map.

ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- International Residential Code, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.212. 

Sec. 26-58. - International Building Code adopted by reference. 
    A certain document is on file in the office of the Building Official, being marked and designated as the International Building Code, 2015 edition, including all Appendix Chapters as published by the International Code Council, Inc., be and is hereby adopted as the Building Code of the City of Weslaco, in the State of Texas; for the control of building and structures as herein provided; and each and all the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Building Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 26-59. 
(Ord. No. 2006-21, §§ 1, 2, 8-1-2006; Ord. No. 2011-07, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2013-10, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 2017-07, § 1, 5-2-2017) 
Sec. 26-59. - Amendments. 
    The International Building Code adopted in section 26-58 is amended in the following respects: 
(1)  Section E101.1: City of Weslaco 
(2)  Section 1612.3: City of Weslaco 
(3)  Section 1612.3: September 1979 
(4)  Section F907.2.3. Group E: A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with section 907.5 shall be installed in Group E occupancies. Smoke alarms shall be installed in educational occupancies, including but not limited to, day care centers, elementary and secondary schools, and all portable buildings. These devices shall be installed in accordance with the rules for partial smoke detection systems, except that day care centers require additional protection in every room in which children sleep. Smoke alarms shall be listed and meet the installation requirements of NFPA 72. 
(5)  Section 114.4.1. Violations penalties: Any person who violates a provision of this code, fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof, or erects, installs, alters, or repairs work in violation of the approved construction documents, directive of the building official, or a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a Class C Misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000). Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(6)  Section 115.2.1. Stop work orders: Upon notice from the building official that work is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, the owner's agent, or the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to give written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(Code 1969, § 8-16.1; Ord. No. 91-07, § 2, 3-5-1991; Ord. No. 2017-07, § 2, 5-12-2017) 
Secs. 26-60-26-106. - Reserved.

Sec. 26-107. - International Plumbing Code adopted by reference.

(Ord. No. 2011-12, §§ 1-3, 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2013-15, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 2017-12, § 1, 5-2-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-12, §§ 1-3, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, repealed former § 26-107, and enacted a new § 26-107 as set out herein. Former § 26-107 pertained to Standard Plumbing Code adopted by reference and derived from Code 1969, § 8-33; Ord. No. 390, § 2, 11-3-1964; Ord. No. 75-12, § 1, 8-5-1975; Ord. No. 77-36, § 1, 1-3-1978; Ord. No. 79-50, 1-8-1980; Ord. No. 84-21, § 1, 8-7-1984; Ord. No. 87-6, § 1, 2-17-1987; Ord. No. 91-05, § 1, 3-5-1991; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 3-7-1995 and Ord. No. 99-24, § 1, 11-16-1999. 
Sec. 26-108. - Amendments. 
    The plumbing code adopted in section 26-107 is amended in the following respects: 
(1)  Section P101.1: City of Weslaco 
(2)  Section P106.6.2: City of Weslaco Master Fee Schedule 
(3)  Section P106.6.3: fifty, ninety 
(4)  Section P108.4. Violations penalties: Any person who violates a provision of this code, fails to complies with an of the requirements thereof, or erects, installs, alters, or repairs work in violation of the approved construction documents, directive of the building official, or a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a Class C Misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more, two thousand dollars ($2,000). Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(5)  Section P108.5. Stop work orders: Upon notice from the building official that work is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, the owner's agent, or the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to given written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(6)  Section P305.4.1: six, six 
(7)  P312.10. Inspection and testing of backflow prevention assemblies. Inspection and testing shall comply with Section 312.10.1. 
(8)  P312.10.1. Inspection and Testing: Residential irrigation backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested at least once every three years. Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer assemblies, double check-valve assemblies, pressure vacuum breaker assemblies, reduced pressure detector fire protection backflow prevention assemblies, double check detector fire protection backflow prevention assemblies, and spill proof vacuum breakers that are not part of a residential irrigation system shall be tested at the time of installation, immediately after repairs or relocation and at least annually. All testing and certification shall be performed by a state-licensed Backflow Prevention Assembly Tester. The Backflow Prevention Assembly Tester must file an original copy of the initial test certification and each annual certification with the water purveyor within ten (10) days of the testing. The testing procedure shall be performed in accordance with one (1) of the following standards: ASSE 5013, ASSE 5015, ASSE 5020, ASSE 5047, ASSE 5048, ASSE 5052, ASSE 5056, CSA B64.10 or CSA B64.10.1. 
(9)  P608.14. Location of backflow preventers: Access shall be provided to backflow preventers as specified by the installation instructions of the approved manufacturer. If needed, additional access and clearance must be provided to allow for the required testing, maintenance, and repair. Access and clearance must require a minimum of one (1) foot (305 mm) between the lowest portion of the assembly and grade, floor, or platform. Installations elevated more than five (5) feet (1.53 m) above the floor or grade, measured from the center line of the valve, must be provided with a permanent platform capable of supporting five hundred (500) pounds and provide mechanical support. 
(10)  P608.16.4. Connections to automatic fire sprinkler systems and standpipe systems: The potable water supply to automatic fire sprinkler and standpipe systems shall be protected against backflow by a double check detector assembly or a reduced pressure principle detector backflow preventer. 
(11)  ..... P608.16.5. Connections to lawn irrigation systems: The potable water supply to lawn irrigation systems shall be protected against backflow by a pressure-type vacuum breaker or a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. A double check valve shall not be used. Where chemicals are introduced into the system, the potable water supply shall be protected against backflow by a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. 
(Code 1969, § 8-34; Ord. No. 91-05, § 2, 3-5-1991; Ord. No. 2017-12, § 2, 5-2-2017) 
Secs. 26-109-26-129. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - UNSANITARY AND DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority concerning substandard building, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.001; additional authority to secure substandard building, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 214.0011, 214.0015. 

Sec. 26-225. - Unlawful to allow building or premises to become dilapidated, substandard, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any building or premises to allow or permit any building or part of any building used for human habitation or used by the general public, or the surroundings thereof, to become dilapidated, substandard, unfit for human habitation and a hazard to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 8-55; Ord. No. 86-24, § 1, 6-17-1986; Ord. No. 87-26, § 1, 8-4-1987) 
Sec. 26-226. - Right of entry for purpose of inspection; penalty. 
    The city manager or authorized agent of the department of code enforcement, shall have the right at all times to enter into and upon any premises or buildings in the city for the purpose of examining and inspecting said premises or buildings for any violation of this article, or for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article. Any individual who interferes with, or obstructs the examination or inspection of, a premises or building by an authorized agent shall be guilty of a misdemeanor violation that shall be punishable by a fine that shall be not less than $1.00 and no more than $500.00. 
(Code 1969, § 8-56; Ord. No. 86-24, § 1, 6-17-1986) 
Sec. 26-227. - Standards for continued use and occupancy. 
    All buildings or premises in the city identified as unsanitary and dangerous under this article, regardless of the date of construction, must comply with the current plumbing code, building code and electrical code of the city. These codes will contain the minimum standards for all premises or buildings in the city in order to allow for their continued use and occupancy. 
(Code 1969, § 8-57; Ord. No. 86-24, § 1, 6-17-1986) 
Sec. 26-228. - Notice to owner. 
    If, after examination and inspection of the premises or building, it is found that the premises or building does not meet the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy, as set out in section 26-227, then the authorized agent of the city shall cause a proper notice to be delivered to the owner of the building or premises by certified mail, return receipt requested, by hand delivery or by publishing said notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least twice before the scheduled public hearing, as set out in section 26-229, when the owner of the building cannot be located. Said notice will contain specific information regarding findings from the inspection or examination, stating how the owner's premises or building is not complying with the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy. The notice shall also contain a date for a public hearing to be conducted in open session of a regularly scheduled city commission meeting. 
(Code 1969, § 8-58; Ord. No. 86-24, § 1, 6-17-1986; Ord. No. 87-26, § 1, 8-4-1987) 
Sec. 26-229. - Public hearing. 
(a)  All public hearings for continued use and occupancy of a building shall be held in open session of a regular city commission meeting. The authorized agent of the city shall present evidence to the city commission of the condition of the premises or building in question and why said condition does not meet the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy as set out in section 26-227. The owner of the premises or building shall have an opportunity to present evidence in his defense. Members of the general public will be given an opportunity to voice their opinions regarding the premises or building that is the subject of the public hearing. 
(b)  If the owner of the premises or building fails or refuses to attend the public hearing, the public hearing must still be conducted. 
(Code 1969, § 8-59; Ord. No. 86-24, § 1, 6-17-1986) 
Sec. 26-230. - Repair or removal of building. 
    If the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy, as set out in section 26-227, are not being met by the building or premises which is the subject of the public hearing, the city commission, depending on the evidence presented at the public hearing, may find that the building or premises is a public nuisance and may direct that the building or premises be either repaired or removed within a reasonable time. At no time will repairs or removal of the building or premises be required less then 15 days from the public hearing day or exceed more than 60 days from the public hearing day. 
(Code 1969, § 8-60; Ord. No. 86-24, § 1, 6-17-1986; Ord. No. 87-26, § 1, 8-4-1987) 
Secs. 26-231-26-279. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CONSTRUCTION AND HOUSING CODES BOARD OF ADJUSTMENTS AND APPEALS 

Sec. 26-280. - Appointment; terms; qualifications for membership. 
(a)  There is hereby created by the city commission a board to be known as the construction and housing codes board of adjustments and appeals, which shall consist of seven members appointed by the city commission. 
(b)  Members of the board shall be appointed for four-year terms. 
(Code 1969, § 8-83; Ord. No. 79-2, § 1, 1-16-1979; Ord. No. 79-5, § 1, 3-6-1979) 
Sec. 26-281. - Meetings; procedure. 
    Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum. Appeals and variances may be granted by a majority of those present, but not less than four affirmative votes shall be required. A board member shall not act in a case in which he has a personal interest. The secretary of the board shall make detailed records of all its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons for its decisions, the vote of each member participating therein, the absence of any member, and any failure of a member to vote. The board shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with local ordinances and laws of the state. The board shall meet at regular intervals, to be determined by the chairman, or in any event, the board shall meet within ten days after notice of appeal has been received. 
(Code 1969, § 8-84; Ord. No. 79-2, § 2, 1-16-1979) 
Sec. 26-282. - Appeals. 
(a)  Generally. The board hereby created shall, from and after January 16, 1979, hear all appeals on requests for variances under the International and Residential Building Code, the city's plumbing code, electrical code, housing code and mechanical code, and the procedure hereby established shall control in all such cases. All parts of the city ordinances adopting such codes, or the codes themselves, establishing a method of appeal or of requesting variance inconsistent with the provisions hereof are hereby repealed, but only to the extent of such inconsistency. Unless affected by the terms of this article, the provisions of the above-named codes shall remain in full force and effect. 
(b)  Building, plumbing, electrical and mechanical codes. Whenever the building official shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of construction proposed to be followed, or materials to be used in the erection or alteration of a building or structure, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the applicable code do not apply, or that an equally good or more desirable form of construction can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the applicable code or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of such building or structure, or his duly authorized agent, may appeal from the decision of the building official to the board. Notice of the appeal shall be in writing and filed within 90 days after the decision is rendered by the building official. A fee of $250.00 shall accompany such notice of appeal. In case of a building or structure which, in the opinion of the building official, is unsafe or dangerous, the building official may, in his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. Appeals hereunder shall be on forms provided by the building official. 
(c)  Housing code. Any person receiving written notice from the building official of deficiencies in his property under this Code may, within 15 days following the date of such notice, enter an appeal in writing to the board. Such appeal shall state the location of the property, the date of the notice of violations, and the number of such notice. The appellant must state the variance or modification requested, the reasons therefor, and the hardship or conditions upon which the appeal is made. A fee of $250.00 shall accompany such notice of appeal. No appeal filed later than 15 days after the date of such notice shall be acted upon by the board, unless the building official shall consent thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 8-85; Ord. No. 79-2, § 3, 1-16-1979) 
Sec. 26-283. - Decisions of the board. 
    Every decision of the board shall be final, subject, however, to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. It shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote upon the decision. Every decision shall be promptly filed in the office of the building official, and shall be open to public inspection. A certified copy shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the building official for two weeks after filing. The board shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. If a decision of the board reverses or modifies a refusal, order, or disallowance of the building official, or varies the application of any provision of the applicable code, the building official shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. 
(Code 1969, § 8-86; Ord. No. 79-2, § 4, 1-16-1979) 
Secs. 26-284-26-315. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ACCESS MANAGEMENT POLICY 

Sec. 26-316. - Access to streets and highways. 
    A roadway network consists of several classifications of roadways each with a different traffic mobility function and commensurate inverse level of access to property. Roadway classes with higher levels of mobility function are necessarily designed to lower levels of access function to minimize conflicts associated with slow moving turning vehicles. Roadways are generally classified as freeways, arterials, collectors, and local streets. 
(1)  Freeways are designed to provide the highest level of mobility and to carry the greatest volume of traffic at the highest safe speeds. Accordingly, freeway main lanes provide no direct access to property and access to the freeway main lanes is provided only at interchanges and ramps designed to minimize the disruption of the mobility function. 
(2)  Arterials generally provide mobility across long distances at lower speeds and provide access at lesser arterials or major collector streets. 
(3)  Collectors provide a more even balance between mobility and access and are intended to carry lower volumes of traffic at lower speeds. Since most of the trips on collectors are shorter distance local trips, these streets can safely provide a higher level of access to local streets. 
(4)  Local streets provide the lowest level of mobility and are intended to provide direct access to properties, preserve the neighborhood environment, and enhance pedestrian and bicycle safety. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, § I(118-26), 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 26-317. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Acceleration lane means a speed-change lane, including lane width tapers, for the purpose of enabling a vehicle to accelerate to a speed compatible with safely merging with through traffic. 
    Access connection means a facility for entry and/or exit such as a driveway, street, or road that connects to the public streets or highways. 
    Commercial means consists of developments including retail, wholesale, office building, warehousing and multi-family buildings consisting of more than five dwelling units. 
    Connection spacing means the distance between connections, which is measured along the edge of the traveled way from the closest edge of pavement of the first access connection to the closest edge of pavement of the second access connection. 
    Directional median opening means an opening in a nontraversable median that accommodates specific movements, such as U-turn movements and/or left-turn movements from the highway, and physically restricts other movements. 
    Divided highway means a highway with a raised median designed to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. 
    Field drive means a limited use driveway for the occasional/infrequent use by equipment used for the purpose of cultivating, planting, and harvesting or maintenance of agricultural land, or by equipment used for ancillary mineral production. 
    Frontage road means a local street or road along an arterial highway allowing control of access and service to adjacent areas and property. A frontage road may also be referred to as a service road. 
    Gross leasable area (GLA) means the area, in square feet, that may be used for leasing space. 
    Industrial consists of establishments for manufacturing, fabrication, industrial, utility, distribution, and transportation uses. These areas may experience heavy truck traffic on a regular basis. 
    Intersection means any at grade connection with a roadway, including two roads or a driveway and a road. 
    Level of service (LOS) means a measure of traffic flow and congestion. It is a qualitative measure describing operational conditions within a traffic stream, generally described in terms of such factors as speed and travel time, freedom to maneuver, traffic interruptions, comfort and convenience, and safety. 
    Limited access roadway means a roadway especially designed for through traffic and to which owners or occupants of abutting land have no right of access. Interstate highways, parkways, and freeways are usually developed as limited access facilities. 
    Local access road means a local public street or road that is generally parallel to a highway for the purpose of serving the collector or local classification function. 
    Marginal access road means the type of street which is used to provide direct access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
    Median means that portion of a divided highway separating the opposing traffic flows. A median may be traversable or nontraversable. 
    Median, nontraversable, means a physical barrier in a roadway or driveway that separates vehicular traffic traveling in opposite directions. Nontraversable medians include physical barriers (such as a concrete barrier, a raised concrete curb and/or island, and a grass or a swale median) that prohibit movement of traffic across the median. 
    Median opening spacing means the allowable spacing between openings in a nontraversable median to allow for crossing the opposing traffic lanes in order to access property or for crossing the median to travel in the opposite direction (U-turn). The distance is measured from centerline to centerline of the openings along the traveled way. 
    Median, traversable, means a median that by its design does not physically discourage vehicles from entering or crossing over it. This may include painted medians. 
    Residential consists of single-family and multi-family buildings consisting of five or fewer dwelling units. 
    Right-of-way means a general term denoting land, property, or interest therein, usually in a strip acquired for or devoted to transportation purposes. 
    Shared access means a single connection serving two or more adjoining lots or parcels. 

    Throat length means the length extending from the property line at the entry into the site to the first vehicle path conflict or intersection with a parking aisle. 
    Vehicle storage length means the length of a driveway, turn lane, bay or other passageway for motor vehicles which is designed to minimize queuing onto surrounding streets. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, § I(118-27), 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 26-318. - Single-family residential. 
(a)  Driveway approaches, including full width of drive and radii, shall not occupy more than 70 percent of the frontage fronting the roadway, or a maximum of 24 feet, whichever is less. 

(b)  Where a subdivision abuts a major thoroughfare (collector or arterial street), lots for single-family residential use shall not front on the thoroughfare. Where conditions are such that vehicular access cannot be provided other than from a thoroughfare, a marginal access street or easement to serve two or more lots may be created with the approval of the director of planning and code enforcement. The marginal access street or easement shall permit entry to the thoroughfare and prevent backing onto the thoroughfare. Marginal access streets or easements shall be included on the subdivision plat. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, § I(118-28), 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 26-319. - Commercial, industrial and medium or high density residential developments. 
(a)  Lots in commercial, industrial and medium or high-density residential developments may have vehicular access from any roadway based on the following criteria: 
(1)  Lots with less than 200 feet of frontage may have one access point. 
(2)  Lots with a frontage of 200 feet or more may have one access for every 200 feet of frontage. 
(3)  Where practicable, all commercial, industrial, retail, and office development lots with less than 400 feet fronting an arterial street shall provide for shared cross access with adjacent lots fronting the arterial, by means of platted common access easement across the lot or recorded instrument providing common access across the lot with adjacent lots. 
(b)  The spacing and location of driveways shall be related to both existing adjacent driveways and those shown on development plans. The spacing between driveways shall depend upon the speed limit or design speed of the intersecting collector or arterial street as shown in Table 26-1, Driveways shall not be permitted in the transition area of any deceleration lane, including tapers, or right turn lane. Spacing between driveways will be measured along the traveled path of the roadway from the edge of one driveway to the closest edge of the next driveway measured at the location where the driveway contacts the abutting roadway: 
Table 26-1: Minimum Spacing Between Driveways 
Design Speed 
(mph) Minimum Driveway Spacing 
(in feet) 30 90 35 165 40 200 45 250 >50 350  
(c)  If the proposed driveway has a corresponding existing driveway across the street of intersection, the centerlines of the drives shall be aligned. If the corresponding driveway alignments cannot be aligned, then an offset of 175 feet from the existing driveway shall be provided to allow adequate left turn storage capacity in advance of each driveway and to avoid the overlap of left-turn lanes. 
(d)  Along either side of any commercial or industrial corner property, the driveway approaches shall be located so as to maintain a minimum distance from the corner of the intersecting roadways equal to 50 percent of the length of the property along the roadway upon which the proposed driveway approach is to be located, or 125 feet, whichever distance is less. 
(e)  Where practicable, driveways shall be planned to match existing openings in medians. In addition, no cuts through the left turn reservoir of a median shall be permitted in order to provide left turn movements for driveway approaches accessing major thoroughfares. 
(f)  In addition to the above requirements, retail establishments with parking lots and short service dwell time (i.e., gas station, convenience store) shall include a minimum six-inch raised curb or other approved traffic barrier, within the lot, along the entire street frontage except at approved driveway approaches and access walks to prevent vehicular access to the street except at designated driveways. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, § I(118-29), 11-6-2007; Ord. No. 2008-16, § I, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 26-320. - Additional access points. 
    Additional access points may be permitted by the director of planning and code enforcement where: 
(1)  The additional land and access points are necessary for beneficial use of land. 
(2)  The additional ingress and egress of vehicles will not seriously disrupt the flow of traffic on the thoroughfare. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, § I(118-30), 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 26-321. - Location of access points. 
    The director of planning and code enforcement will determine the specific location of the access points at such time as a site plan is reviewed prior to the issuance of a building permit. The criteria of placement will include: 
(1)  The location shall minimize conflicts with vehicle turning movements. 
(2)  The location shall be located as far as practicable from the other driveway locations. 
(3)  Driveways along an arterial within 400 feet of a major intersection, such as the intersection of two arterial streets or the intersection of a collector and an arterial street, may be restricted to right turn movements. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, § I(118-31), 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 26-322. - Driveway throat or vehicle storage length. 
    The throat length shall be designed in accordance with the anticipated storage length for entering and exiting vehicles to prevent vehicles from queuing into the flow of traffic on the public street or causing unsafe conflicts with on-site circulation. All vehicle storage shall be provided within the site. Standards are set forth in Table 26-2. These standards are not intended for minor driveways. 
Table 26-2: Minimum Driveway Throat Lengths 
Land Use Throat Length or Vehicle Storage Length Shopping centers >200,000 GLA Throat length 200 feet Developments <200,000 GLA not otherwise enumerated in this table Throat length 75 feet Unsignalized driveways not otherwise enumerated in this table Throat length 40-foot minimum Residential subdivision entryway (private, gated entries) The minimum entryway vehicle storage length shall be 40 feet.
