    The city prohibits grease interceptor waste collection and disposal by companies not franchised by this article and will impose a penalty of $500.00 per day, per customer for companies operating within the city limits without a franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § I(16-38), 1-4-2005) 
Sec. 70-85. - Certain model standards to be used. 
    The city desires to follow certain elements of the state commission on environmental quality's (TCEQ) model standards for grease management regarding the cleaning schedule for grease interceptors. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § I(16-39), 1-4-2005) 
Sec. 70-86. - Evacuations based upon schedule. 
    All existing grease interceptors shall be evacuated based on the schedules specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § I(16-40), 1-4-2005) 
Sec. 70-87. - Installation of grease interceptors. 
    All new grease interceptors installed within the city for all new commercial, institutional, or industrial food service or processing facilities shall be a minimum of 1,000 gallons in size and constructed and installed in accordance with chapter 26, article IV. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § I(16-41), 1-4-2005) 
Sec. 70-88. - Issuance of franchise agreements. 
    The city shall issue franchise agreements to licensed grease trap and grit trap waste haulers who agree to comply with the City of Weslaco's adopted grease and grit trap standards and the requirements of a grease and grit trap franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § II, 1-4-2005; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1(B), 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 70-89. - Vendor allowance to city. 
    The chosen vendor shall pay or allow the City to collect 10% of the fees charged by the vendor under the Agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § III, 1-4-2005) 
Sec. 70-90. - Preamble adopted. 
    All facts recited in the preamble herein are hereby found to be true and correct and are herein adopted by the Weslaco City Commission as if fully set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § IV, 1-4-2005) 
Sec. 70-91. - Term, validity of franchise agreement. 
    The franchise agreement issued by the City shall be valid for a term of seven years. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § V, 1-4-2005; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1(C), 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 70-92. - Authorization of mayor. 
    The city commission authorizes the mayor to execute all franchise agreements with qualified licensed grease trap and grit trap waste haulers who agree to comply with the city's adopted grease and grit trap standard and the requirements of a grease and grit trap franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § VI, 1-4-2005; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1(D), 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 70-93. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The City shall have the power to administer and enforce provisions of this article as may be required by governing law. Any person violating any provision of this article is subject to suit for injunctive relief as well as prosecution for criminal violations. Any person violating any provision of this article, including the collection or disposal of grease and grit trap/interceptor waste collection by companies not franchised by this article or the failure or refusal of a generator of grease and grit trap/interceptor waste to use or pay for the collection and disposal services provided for herein may be fined not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day, per customer. Each day that a provision of this article is violated shall constitute a separate offense. An offense under this article is a misdemeanor. Nothing in this article shall be construed as a waiver of the City's right to bring a civil action to enforce the provisions of this article and to seek remedies as allowed by law, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Injunctive relief to prevent specific conduct that violates this article or to require specific conduct that is necessary for compliance with this article; 
(2)  A civil penalty up to $500.00 a day when it is shown that the defendant was actually notified of the provisions of this article and after receiving notice committed acts in violation of this article or failed to take action necessary for compliance with this article; and 
(3)  Other available relief. 
(Ord. No. 2004-60, § VII, 1-4-2005) 
Chapter 74 - HUMAN RELATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING PRACTICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal fair housing ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.903. 

Sec. 74-19. - Discrimination to constitute misdemeanor; penalty. 
    Discrimination on the basis of race, color, creed, familial status, national origin, sex, or handicap status in the sale or rental of housing, in the financing of housing, or in the provision of brokerage services is against the public policy of the city, and any act of discrimination shall constitute a misdemeanor and subject the offender to a fine of not more than $1,000.00. 
(Code 1969, § 161/2-17; Ord. No. 78-10, § 2, 6-13-1978; Ord. No. 85-30, § 1, 9-17-1985) 
Sec. 74-20. - Prohibited acts specified. 
(a)  Discrimination in the sale or renting of housing. No person shall: 
(1)  Refuse to sell or rent, after the making of a bona fide offer, or refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, otherwise make unavailable, or deny a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status. 
(2)  Discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status. 
(3)  Make, print or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published, any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status or an intention to make such preference, limitation or discrimination. 
(4)  Represent to any person because of race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available. 
(5)  Induce or attempt to induce, for profit, any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person of a particular race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status. 
(b)  Discrimination in the financing of housing. It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration, or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance because of the race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status of such person or of any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance or the purpose of such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of the dwelling in relation to which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given. 
(c)  Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services. It shall be unlawful to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against him in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation on account of race, color, religion, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status. 
(Code 1969, § 161/2-18; Ord. No. 78-10, § 3, 6-13-1978; Ord. No. 85-30, § 2, 9-17-1985) 
Sec. 74-21. - Exclusions from applicability of nondiscrimination provisions. 
    This article shall not apply to the sale or renting of a single-family house by its owner or prevent a religious organization, association or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in connection with a religious organization, association or society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, familial status, sex, national origin, or handicap status; nor shall anything in this article prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public which, as an incident to its primary purpose, provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. The provisions of 42 USC 3603(b) and 42 USC 3603(c) shall govern the exemption hereinabove provided for with respect to the sale or rental of a single-family house by its owners, and the provisions thereof are incorporated herein by reference for all purposes. 
(Code 1969, § 161/2-19; Ord. No. 78-10, § 3, 6-13-1978; Ord. No. 85-30, § 2, 9-17-1985) 
Sec. 74-22. - Interference, coercion or intimidation with respect to protected rights declared unlawful. 
    It shall further be unlawful under this article to coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, on account of his having exercised or enjoyed, or on account of having aided or encouraged other persons in the exercise or enjoyment of any right granted or protected by this article, and any person violating the provisions hereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $1,000.00. 
(Code 1969, § 161/2-20; Ord. No. 78-10, § 4, 6-13-1978) 
Sec. 74-23. - Fair housing officer designated. 
    The city manager is hereby designated as the fair housing officer of the city, and any person aggrieved by an adverse decision of any vendor, lessor, financing institution, real estate broker, or any person who feels he has been interfered with, coerced or intimidated with respect to the rights granted by this article shall make complaint to the fair housing officer of the city on a form provided by said officer for that purpose. Upon receipt of any such complaint, the fair housing officer shall investigate the complaint and shall attempt to conciliate the dispute to secure voluntary compliance with the provisions hereof. In the event voluntary compliance is not forthcoming, the fair housing officer shall forward the aggrieved person's complaint to the appropriate department or agency of the United States government for action in conformity with 42 USC 3601 et seq. The fair housing officer is also authorized to cooperate with the secretary of housing and urban development in the enforcement of the Fair Housing Law (42 USC 3601-3619) and may receive reimbursement on the behalf of the municipality, for services rendered in the enforcement of said act. 
(Code 1969, § 161/2-21; Ord. No. 78-10, § 4, 6-13-1978) 
Chapter 78 - LIBRARIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Powers and duties of librarian. 
    The librarian of the city's public library system shall be the executive and administrative head of the library system and shall be responsible to the city manager for the efficient operation and management of the library. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1; Ord. No. 417, § 6, 11-1-1966) 
Secs. 78-2-78-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY BOARD 

Sec. 78-21. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a public library board to be known as the "Weslaco Public Library Board." 
(Code 1969, § 17-12; Ord. No. 417, § 1, 11-1-1966) 
Sec. 78-22. - Composition, generally; appointment of members. 
    The library board shall be composed of five members appointed by the City Commission, with the advice and approval of the City Commission. 
(Code 1969, § 17-13; Ord. No. 417, §§ 1, 2, 11-1-1966; Ord. No. 94-03, § 1, 2-1-1994) 
Sec. 78-23. - Ex officio members. 
    The mayor, the city manager, and the librarian of the city's public library system shall be ex officio members of the library board without voting rights. 
(Code 1969, § 17-14; Ord. No. 417, § 2, 11-1-1966) 
Sec. 78-24. - Terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
    Members shall be appointed for terms of two years, provided that, where the appointment is to fill a vacancy of an existing member prior to expiration of his term, such appointment shall be for the remainder of the term of his predecessor. Upon the expiration of each term of each of the five members, terms shall expire on January 15 of each year until their successors are appointed and shall qualify. 
(Code 1969, § 17-15; Ord. No. 417, § 2, 11-1-1966) 
Sec. 78-25. - Secretary. 
    The librarian of the public library system shall be ex officio secretary of the library board. 
(Code 1969, § 17-16; Ord. No. 417, § 6, 11-1-1966) 
Sec. 78-26. - General duties. 
    The librarian shall be responsible to the city manager for the efficient and proper operation of the city's public library system. The city commission shall determine and establish the general policies and programs for the operation, conduct and management of the library system. 
(Code 1969, § 17-17; Ord. No. 417, §§ 4, 5, 11-1-1966) 
Sec. 78-27. - Bylaws, rules and regulations. 
    Upon the appointment of the library board and during its continuance, such board shall formulate and maintain such bylaws, rules and regulations for the conduct of its meetings. 
(Code 1969, § 17-18; Ord. No. 417, §§ 3, 5, 11-1-1966) 
Sec. 78-28. - Authority to accept donations, gifts and bequests. 
    The library board can accept and receive donations, with the permission of the city commission, for the use and benefit of the city's public library system. 
(Code 1969, § 17-22; Ord. No. 417, § 5, 11-1-1966) 
Chapter 82 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES AND PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipality may not enact or enforce law making conduct covered under state penal code an offense subject to criminal penalty, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 1.08. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Arrest without warrant. 
    The chief of police, his deputies and the city policemen shall have authority to arrest without warrant any person found in suspicious places under circumstances which reasonably show that such person has been guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or threatens, or is about to commit, some offense against the laws. 
(Code 1969, § 18-1; Ord. No. 199, § 1, 8-7-1951) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, see Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 214. 
Sec. 82-2. - Franchise required for community antenna television system. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the term "community antenna television system" includes, but is not limited to, the use of coaxial cable, microwave relay, leased wire, and any other method by which television signals may be brought into the home of a subscriber for a fee. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a community antenna television system within the city limits, unless such person has first obtained a valid franchise from the city. 
(c)  No franchise to provide telephone or electrical power service to the citizens of the city shall include the right to operate a community antenna television system, and no person holding such a franchise shall operate such a system, unless he obtains a separate franchise specifically authorizing the operation of a community antenna television system. 
(Code 1969, § 18-2; Ord. No. 402, § 1, 10-12-1965; Ord. No. 408, § 1, 1-8-1966) 
Sec. 82-3. - Commission permission for oil and gas drilling and mining operations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct drilling or mining operations for discovery and production of oil, gas or other minerals within the city without first securing permission from the city commission to engage in such activity at the proposed location. 
(Code 1969, § 18-3; Ord. No. 262, §§ 1, 2, 1-3-1956) 
State Law reference- Home-rule municipal authority for regulation of exploration and development of mineral interests, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 92.007. 
Sec. 82-4. - Abandoned iceboxes, refrigerators, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or dangerously expose any refrigerator, icebox, cold storage box, or any container having attached or affixed to the door a spring lock, or a latch fastener or lock that permits the opening of the door from the outside only, unless such refrigerator, icebox, cold storage box or container has had removed therefrom the door, or the latch, lock or fastener attached to said door. 
(Code 1969, § 18-6; Ord. No. 240, § 1, 5-18-1954) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, leaving refrigerator or container accessible to children, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.012; types of containers, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.011. 
Sec. 82-5. - Discharging firearms, air guns, etc. 
    No person shall fire or discharge any gun, revolver, pistol, or other firearm, or shoot any air rifle, BB gun, pellet gun or any other weapon which, by any force or source of energy, propels any solid object at a speed dangerous to the human eye, life or limb, within the city. 
(Code 1969, § 18-11; Ord. No. 136, § 1, 2-14-1947; Ord. No. 315, § 1, 8-4-1959) 
State Law reference- Municipality may regulate discharge of firearms, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 229.001(b)(2). 
Sec. 82-6. - Unlawful to swim in canals, ditches. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim in any canal, drain ditch or storm sewer within the city or owned by the city outside the city limits. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500.00. 
(Code 1969, § 18-12; Ord. No. 69-16, § 9, 5-6-1969; Ord. No. 76-11, § 11, 7-6-1976) 
Sec. 82-7. - Parking lots. 
(a)  Defined; purpose and applicability. The term "parking lot," when used in this section, means any area in, at, or adjacent to a restaurant, drive-in restaurant, store, retail or whole-sale business establishment, office building, professional building, church building, bank building, or recreational building hereinafter referred to as a premises, or any public building or space used, designed, or intended for the parking of any type of vehicle, including motor vehicles, by members of the general public, and maintained for the convenience of customers, clients, patients, members or patrons of one or more business establishments, public offices, or organizations. For the purpose of the public peace, health, safety, morals, general welfare and the public interest, all parking lots, including driveways, exits and entrances thereto, are hereby declared to be public places, and it is contrary to the public interest, peace, morals, health and general welfare of the city to permit litter on such places, to park, drive or operate motor vehicles thereon in any manner prohibited by this section, or to engage in any conduct thereon in the manner prohibited by this section. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. The following acts or conduct of any person on entering, driving on, parking on or leaving any parking lot are hereby declared to be unlawful, and any person found guilty of any such act or conduct shall be guilty of a misdemeanor: 
(1)  Entering a parking lot in a motor vehicle of any kind and using said parking lot for racing or as a shortcut to another property or street; 
(2)  Racing the motor of a vehicle, needlessly bringing to a sudden start or stop any vehicle, blowing the horn of such vehicle needlessly, or playing the radio of such vehicle at a high volume, or creating any loud or unseemly noise, nuisance or disturbance whereby the quiet and good order of the premises or the adjacent neighborhood are disturbed; 
(3)  Two or more persons congregating inside or outside a motor vehicle parked thereon or on or off a bicycle or motorcycle when not otherwise engaged in a lawful pursuit relating to the use of the premises and without the owner's consent; 
(4)  Throwing, depositing or leaving or permitting to come to rest upon any parking lot any litter, except in the receptacles provided for such litter, as hereinafter set forth. The term "litter," when used in this section, means any trash, paper, napkins, straws, cups or containers made of paper, plastic, or other similar material, bottles, glass, candy or gum wrappers, remnants of foods, cans or remnants or parts thereof, or any material of an unsanitary nature; and 
(5)  Leaving a motor vehicle, bicycle or motorcycle unattended on a parking lot, except for the purpose of entering into a premises or returning therefrom, except with the consent and approval of the owner or operator or manager of such parking lot. 
For purpose of this section, the fact that a premises is closed shall constitute prima facie proof that a person is not engaged in a lawful pursuit relating to the use of the premises. Furthermore, if any parking lot is clearly marked by a sign or device declaring time limits or other restrictions relating to parking, as enumerated in this section, then a violation by any person of such restrictions shall be prima facie proof of such owner's nonconsent to any person parking or congregating on such parking lot. 
(c)  Penalty. All misdemeanor violations under this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $1.00 and not more than $400.00. 
(d)  Authority to remove violators. The owner, lessee, manager, or operator of any parking lot shall have the right to have removed from such parking lot any unauthorized person who is found on said parking lot after business hours, provided that there has been placed on such premises in a conspicuous place a sign in letters at least three inches in height, which shall read as follows: 
WARNING: UNAUTHORIZED PRESENCE AFTER BUSINESS HOURS SUBJECTS YOU TO BEING PROSECUTED FOR TRESPASSING. FINE UP TO $400.00. 
(Code 1969, § 18-13; Ord. No. 85-34, §§ 1, 2, 11-19-1985) 
Sec. 82-8. - Concealed handguns prohibited. 
(a)  The carrying of any concealed handgun by any person, unless such person is a licensed peace officer under the laws of the state and is carrying a concealed handgun under the course and scope of his employment, is prohibited on all city owned premises for which such prohibition is valid under state law. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry a concealed handgun in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(b)  This section is intended to be interpreted liberally so as to prohibit handguns from any and all city property that state law allows municipalities to regulate. The city manager is hereby authorized to post notice of this prohibition at the entrance of all city premises. Any person carrying a concealed handgun in violation of this prohibition shall be considered to be entering the premises of the city in violation of V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 30.05, such section being the criminal trespass statute of the state. 
(c)  Any violation of the provisions in this section shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Code 1969, § 18-14; Ord. No. 96-13, § 1, 5-7-1996) 
State Law reference- Trespass by holder of license to carry concealed handgun, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 30.06; places where weapons are prohibited, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 46.03. 
Secs. 82-9-82-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ABANDONED VEHICLES AND TRAILERS 

Sec. 82-35. - Removal. 
    When a vehicle is determined by the city traffic engineer to be abandoned on any highway, street, avenue or alley in the city, the chief of police may order such vehicle removed to a convenient storage place. 
(Code 1969, § 18-22; Ord. No. 69-18, § 7, 5-6-1969) 
Sec. 82-36. - Charges. 
    For all abandoned vehicles removed from the streets, a reasonable towing charge and an additional charge not to exceed actual expenses may be made for notifying the owner thereof, preparing advertisement of sale of such vehicle, posting notices of sale, and the sale and redemption. 
(Code 1969, § 18-23; Ord. No. 69-18, § 7, 5-6-1969) 
Sec. 82-37. - Sale. 
    If any abandoned vehicle removed from the streets pursuant to this article is not redeemed, sale of such vehicle shall be made according to procedures for sale in foreclosure of a mechanic's lien for labor done. 
(Code 1969, § 18-24; Ord. No. 69-18, § 7, 5-6-1969) 
Secs. 82-38-82-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JUNKED VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Junked vehicles as nuisance, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.072; abatement of nuisance of junked vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 683.071-683.078. 

Sec. 82-63. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, whenever used or referred to in this article, shall have the following respective meanings unless a different meaning is indicated by the context: 
    Demolisher means any person whose business is to convert a motor vehicle into processed scrap or scrap metal, or otherwise to wreck or dismantle motor vehicles. 
    Junked vehicle means any motor vehicle that is self-propelled and: 
(1)  Does not have lawfully attached to it: 
a.  An unexpired license plate; or 
b.  A valid motor vehicle inspection certificate; and 
(2)  Is: 
a.  Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or 
b.  Inoperable and has remained inoperable for more than: 
1.  Seventy-two consecutive hours, if the vehicle is on public property; or 
2.  Thirty consecutive days, if the vehicle is on private property. 
    Motor vehicle means any motor vehicle subject to registration pursuant to the Texas Certificate of Title Act. 
    Police department shall mean the police department of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 18-28; Ord. No. 76-28, § 2, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 2001-03, § I, 3-20-2001) 
Sec. 82-64. - Declared a public nuisance. 
    Junked vehicles which are located in any place where they are visible from a public place or from a public right-of-way or which are located on public property are hereby declared to be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the general public, in that the same tend to reduce the value of public property, to invite vandalism, to create fire hazards, to constitute an attractive nuisance to children and to be detrimental to the economic welfare of the city and the state as a whole by contributing to urban blight. Such vehicles are therefore declared to be a public nuisance and subject to abatement by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 18-29; Ord. No. 76-28, § 3, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-65. - Creating or maintaining a junked vehicle as a public nuisance prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain upon private or public property, except as herein provided, within the city limits of the city any junked vehicle or parts or portions thereof for any period of time in excess of 72 consecutive hours, if the vehicle is on public property, or 30 days, if the vehicle is on private property. 
(Code 1969, § 18-30; Ord. No. 76-28, § 4, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 2001-03, § I, 3-20-2001) 
Sec. 82-66. - Proceedings to abate public nuisance-Private property. 
(a)  Whenever it is brought to the attention of the chief of police of the city that a public nuisance is being maintained on private property, the chief shall send or cause to be sent to the owner or occupant of the private premises whereupon such public nuisance exists a notice stating the nature of the public nuisance and that it must be removed and abated within ten days from the date of said notice, and further advising the owner or occupant of the premises that such owner or occupant has the right to a hearing before the municipal judge of the city, provided request for a hearing is made before the expiration of the seven day period. 
(b)  The notice herein provided to be sent to the chief of police of the city or his agent shall be given to the property owner personally in writing or sent by certified or registered mail with return receipt requested to the owner's address, as recorded in the appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which the property is located, or, if personal notice cannot be obtained, by posting notice on the junked vehicle for which the violation relates. If the notice is mailed by the city and postal service returns the notice as "refused" or "undeclared," the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice is considered as delivered, and official action to abate said such nuisance shall be contained to a date not less than ten days from the date of return. In the notice provided under this section, the city shall inform the property owner that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the city, without further notice, may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this section occurs within the one-year period and the city has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the city, without notice, may take any action permitted by this section. 
(Code 1969, § 18-31; Ord. No. 76-28, § 5, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 2001-03, § I, 3-20-2001) 
Sec. 82-67. - Same-On public property. 
(a)  Whenever it is brought to the attention of the chief of police of the city that a public nuisance is being maintained on public property or on a public right-of-way, the chief shall send or cause to be sent to the owner or occupant of the public premises or to the owner or occupant of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way whereupon such public nuisance exists a notice stating the nature of the public nuisance and that it must be removed and abated within ten days from the date of said notice and further advising the owner or occupant of the premises that such owner or occupant has the right to a hearing before the municipal judge of the city, provided that request for a hearing is made before the expiration of the ten-day period. 
(b)  The notice herein provided to be sent by the chief of police of the city or his agent shall be given to the property owners personally in writing or sent by certified or registered mail with return receipt requested to the owners address, as recorded in the appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which the property is located. If notice is mailed by the city and postal service returns the notice as "refused" or "undeclared," the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice is considered as delivered, and official action to abate said such nuisance shall be contained to a date not less than ten days from the date of return. In the notice provided under this section, the city shall inform the property owner that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the city, without further notice, may correct the violation at the owners expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this section occurs within the one-year period, and the city has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the city, without notice, may take any action permitted by this section. 
(Code 1969, § 18-32; Ord. No. 76-28, § 6, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 2001-03, § I, 3-20-2001) 
Sec. 82-68. - Same-Hearing in municipal court; order of municipal judge. 
    If requested in a timely manner by the owner or occupant of the private premises, the public premises or the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way whereupon such public nuisance is alleged to be maintained, a hearing shall be held before the municipal judge of the city prior to the removal of the vehicle or part thereof. After such hearing, should the municipal judge determine that a public nuisance is being maintained upon the property in question, he shall enter an order requiring the removal of the vehicle or part thereof, and such order shall include a description of the vehicle and the correct identification number and license number of the vehicle, if available at the site. 
(Code 1969, § 18-33; Ord. No. 76-28, § 7, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-69. - Same-Removal of vehicle. 
(a)  If no hearing is requested as provided in this article, it shall be the duty of the person notified to comply with the provisions of the notice given him and to abate such nuisance within ten days after the date of receipt of such notice. If a hearing is requested, as provided for in this article, and an order of removal is entered by the municipal judge, it shall be the duty of the person requesting the hearing to comply with the order of removal and to remove and abate such nuisance within ten days from the entry of such order. 
(b)  If such a nuisance is not abated within the time period allowed, the chief of police of the city may remove the vehicle or cause it to be removed to the proper storage area. 
(Code 1969, § 18-34; Ord. No. 76-28, § 8, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 2001-03, § I, 3-20-2001) 
Sec. 82-70. - Notice to state highway department of vehicle removal required. 
    The chief of police shall give notice to the state highway department, within five days after the date of removal, identifying the vehicle or part thereof so removed for cancellation of the certificate of title to such vehicle pursuant to state law. 
(Code 1969, § 18-35; Ord. No. 76-28, § 10, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-71. - Vehicles not to be made operable. 
    After a vehicle has been removed under the terms of this article, it shall not be reconstructed or made operable. 
(Code 1969, § 18-36; Ord. No. 76-28, § 9, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-72. - Sale or disposal of removed vehicle. 
    When any junked vehicle has been removed by the police department to the storage area of the city and has remained in such storage area for ten days or more, it shall be the duty of the chief of police of the city to dispose of the same by removal to a scrap yard or by sale to a demolisher for the highest bid or offer received, or to remove the same to any suitable site operated by the city for processing as scrap or salvage. Should the junked vehicle be sold to a demolisher or as salvage, the proceeds of such sale shall be first applied to the cost of removal and storage, and the balance, if any, shall be paid to the person entitled thereto, either a lienholder or the owner. 
(Code 1969, § 18-37; Ord. No. 76-28, § 13, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-73. - Reserved. 
Sec. 82-74. - Exemptions from article provisions. 
(a)  The provisions herein contained do not apply to: 
(1)  Any vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other public or private property; 
(2)  A vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer or a junkyard; or 
(3)  An unlicensed, operable or inoperable antique and special interest vehicle stored by a collector on his property, provided that the vehicles and the outdoor storage areas are maintained in such a manner that they do not constitute a health hazard and are screened from ordinary public view by means of a fence, rapidly growing trees, shrubbery or other appropriate means. 
(b)  The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: 
(1)  The term "antique vehicle" means a passenger car or truck that is at least 25 years old. 
(2)  The term "motor vehicle collector" means a person who: 
a.  Owns one or more antique or special interest vehicles; and 
b.  Acquires, collects, or disposes of an antique or special interest vehicle or part of an antique or special interest vehicle for personal use to restore and preserve an antique or special interest vehicle for historic interest. 
(3)  The term "special interest vehicle" means a motor vehicle of any age that has not been changed from original manufacturer's specifications and, because of its historic interest, is being preserved by a hobbyist. 
(Code 1969, § 18-39; Ord. No. 76-28, § 12, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-75. - Right of entry on private property; authority of municipal court. 
    The chief of police or his duly authorized agent may enter upon private property for the purposes specified in this article and to examine vehicles or parts thereof, to obtain information as to the identity of vehicles, and to remove or cause the removal of a vehicle or parts thereof declared to be a nuisance. The municipal court of the city shall have the power and authority to issue all orders necessary to enforce the procedures established by this article. 
(Code 1969, § 18-40; Ord. No. 76-28, § 14, 12-7-1976) 
Sec. 82-76. - Failure or refusal to comply with abatement order; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person directed to remove or abate a nuisance to fail or refuse to comply therewith or to fail to remove such junked vehicle within the time provided by such order. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate the terms and provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 or more than $500.00, and each and every day this article is violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 18-41; Ord. No. 76-28, § 15, 12-7-1976) 
Secs. 82-77-82-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED AND SURPLUS PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Disposition of most unclaimed and abandoned property, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 18.17. 

Sec. 82-96. - Unclaimed property. 
(a)  Responsibility for possession and processing of confiscated property. 
(1)  All property seized by the police department or otherwise acquired by the police department as a result of police department operations and otherwise owned by third parties shall, after initial processing in accordance with the code of criminal procedures of the state by the responsible officer, be turned over to the Custodian for Evidence for safekeeping and disposition according to the terms of this article or as otherwise specified by the code of criminal procedures of the state. 
(2)  The term "unclaimed property," as used in this article, shall mean any such property turned over to the Custodian for Evidence which has not been restored to its owner under the provisions of Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 47.01 et seq., as such provisions presently exists or as may hereafter be amended, and shall have remained unclaimed by its rightful owner for a period of 30 days from the date of acquisition by the city police department or from the date that the property is no longer required to be held by the department for evidentiary purposes or as otherwise required under the code of criminal procedures of the state. 
(b)  Processing owners' claim for property. All persons claiming ownership and desiring the return of property acquired by the police department shall file an application form, which shall be promulgated by the Custodian for Evidence, and present proof of purchase ownership papers with serial number or other sufficient evidence relating to ownership of the claimed property. The Custodian for Evidence shall, after making record thereof, turn over any such claimed property upon the presentation of satisfactory evidence of ownership to the person making such claim. Where any such claim is based upon a general description of the property without other evidence of ownership, the special services division shall record such claim and hold such property for a period of six months, and if no other person shall make a claim for the property, the property will then be released to the original claimant after said six-month period. Should any other party make a claim for property being held during said six-month period, the matter will be referred to the municipal court of the city for an evidentiary hearing, after which the municipal court judge shall make a ruling for the disposition of the property based on such hearing. If any claimant disagrees with the decision of the Custodian for Evidence to hold such property for said six-month period, such claimant shall, within five days of the decision of the Custodian for Evidence, file a written appeal with the chief of police, who shall hold a hearing relating to such appeal and shall have the authority to release such property or affirm the decision of the special services division. 
(c)  Procedures for selling unclaimed property. 
(1)  The Custodian for Evidence shall be responsible for mailing a notice to the last known address of the owner, if known, of any unclaimed property by certified mail. Such notice shall describe the property, shall give the name and address of the officer holding such property, and shall state that if the owner does not claim such property within six months from the date of notice, such property shall be sold, and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and the costs of the sale, shall be placed in the city general fund. 
(2)  If the owner of such property is unknown or if the address of the owner is unknown, the service bureau shall cause to be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city a notice containing the description of the property held, the name of the owner, if known, the name and address of the officer holding such property, and a statement that if the owner does not claim such property within six months from the date of the publication, such property will thereafter be sold, and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and cost of the sale, will be placed in the city general fund. 
(3)  Any person making a claim for property after notice is provided shall follow the same procedures as provided for in subsection (b) of this section; provided, however, that for property being claimed by general description for which a city six-month holding period has been established, the time period for claims made as a result of this action shall be the lesser of six months or the period between filing the claim and the date of sale, as provided for herein. 
(4)  The sale of any property hereunder shall be preceded by notice published once at least three weeks prior to the date of such sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, stating a description of the property, the name of the owner, if known, and the date and place that such sale will occur. If a representative of the purchasing agent shall consider any bid as insufficient, he need not sell such property, but may decline such bid and re-offer such property for sale or otherwise put such property to use or dispose of such property upon written order of the chief of police. 
(5)  The real owner of any property sold shall have the right to file a claim to the proceeds of such sale with the city manager of the city. If a claim is allowed by the city manager, the director of finance shall pay the owner such funds as were paid into the general fund of the city as proceeds of the sale, less costs of holding of the sale and storage. If the claim is denied by the city manager, or if the city manager fails to act upon any such claim within 90 days from the date of claim, the claimant may sue the city in a court of competent jurisdiction in the county, and upon sufficient proof of ownership, cover judgment against the city to recover the proceeds of the sale, as provided in this section. Failure to initiate such suit within six months from the date authorized for the filing of such claim shall be deemed a waiver of any right to cover the proceeds of such sale. 
(d)  Items exempted from this section. The disposition of gambling paraphernalia, prohibited weapons, criminal instruments, explosive weapons, chemical dispensing devices, and other contraband as defined in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 18.01 et seq. shall be processed, returned or destroyed according to the applicable provisions of Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 18.01 et seq. as such provisions presently exist or may hereinafter be amended, and shall not be subject to the procedures for processing required for unclaimed property as provided for in this article. 
(e)  All other unclaimed, abandoned or personal property. All unclaimed or abandoned property or personal property of every kind, except whiskey, wine and beer, held by the police department after it has complied with this section shall be inventoried and, unless ordered destroyed or returned to the owner, delivered for sale to the city's purchasing agent, who shall hold a sale or auction. After deducting the reasonable expenses of keeping such property and costs of the sale, the proceeds shall then be placed in the city's general fund. 
(Code 1969, § 18-44; Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 4-1-1986) 
Sec. 82-97. - Sale of surplus items belonging to the city. 
(a)  Designation of surplus items. The purchasing agent of the city shall, from time to time, designate all personal property belonging to the city that is not functioning, obsolete, broken, irreparable or no longer being used by the city as surplus items. All surplus items shall be indexed according to serial number and general description. 
(b)  Notice of auction. The purchasing agent shall cause a list of such items to be published in a newspaper of general circulation with the notice of the city to hold an auction of these surplus items at a time and place to be designated by the city. The auction shall be held only after the notice of the auction has been printed twice. The auction shall be held no later than ten days after the second published notice of the auction. 
(c)  Auctions. All surplus items will be sold to the highest bidder paying cash on the day of the auction. All surplus items not sold at the auction shall be auctioned at a later time or disposed of by the purchasing agent, at his discretion. 
(d)  Proceeds. All proceeds from said auction shall be delivered by the purchasing agent to the director of finance of the city no later than five days after the date of the auction. All auction proceeds will be deposited into the general fund for the city. 
(Code 1969, § 18-45; Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 4-1-1986) 
Secs. 82-98-82-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BURGLAR AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Burglar alarm systems, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.191 et seq.; duration of municipal permit, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.193; maximum fee for annual municipal permit, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.194; local governments cannot enact ordinances inconsistent with state law regarding fire alarm systems, V.A.T.S. Insurance Code, art. 5.43-2, § 3(a); license holders for emergency alarm systems installation and operation, exempt from certain local regulations, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1702.134; municipality may charge reasonable inspection fees for device causing five false alarms in 12-month period, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1702.134(2)(c). 

Sec. 82-123. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the purpose and intent of this article to protect the emergency services of the city police department from misuse and to defray the costs of administrating the city Burglar and Robbery Alarm Ordinance through permanent and service fees, to encourage the improvements in reliability of burglary and robbery systems and devices to ensure that police personnel shall not be diverted from responding to real criminal activity as a result of responding to false burglary and robbery alarms, to reduce the number of false alarms and the amount of police time and resources expended on responding to false alarms, and to ensure that a responsible person is accessible within a reasonable amount of time to take custody of the site of a burglary or robbery alarm, and to provide certain minimum standards, safeguards, and regulations for burglary or robbery alarms. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-68, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-124. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm site means a single premises or street address served by one or more alarm systems. Each tenant unit in a multiunit structure or complex shall be considered a separate alarm site if served by a separate alarm system. 
    Alarm system means any assembly of mechanical or electrical equipment installed and maintained for the purpose of signaling the police department of a burglary or a robbery occurring or about to occur at the alarm site, including equipment which signals the department through a third-party central alarm station. 
    Automatic dialing device means any device connected to an alarm system which automatically sends a prerecorded message or code signal over telephone lines, indicating the activation of the alarm system to a predetermined location. 
    Bona fide medical emergency means circumstances of an individual which require medical attention or treatment administered to the individual by qualified personnel. 
    Burglary means any of the acts described in V.C.T.A., Penal Code § 30.02. 
    Chief of police means the head of the police department of the city or his authorized agent. 
    Common cause means a technical difficulty or malfunction which causes an alarm system to emit or report more than one false alarm intermittently. 
    False alarm notification means the activation of an alarm system that results in notification to the police department when the responding officer, on reasonable investigation, finds no evidence of unauthorized intrusion, attempted unauthorized intrusion, robbery, or attempted robbery. 
    Permit means a certificate of authorization to operate an alarm system issued by the police department to the owner or person in control of the premises where a permitted alarm system is located. 
    Permit holder means any person to whom an alarm system permit is issued. 
    Police department means the police department of the city or any authorized agent of such department. 
    Respond means the act of sending a police officer to an alarm site after the police department receives a report of an alarm at such alarm site. 
    Robbery means any of the acts described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code §§ 29.02 and 29.03. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-69, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-125. - Coverage. 
    This article shall apply only to burglary and robbery alarm systems installed and maintained on residential, nonresidential, or commercial sites. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-70, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-126. - Permit application. 
(a)  Any person required to obtain an alarm permit shall file a fully completed application therefor with the police department, which shall conduct an investigation for each application as deemed appropriate by the chief of police. 
(b)  Under this article, a nonrefundable fee shall be charged for the processing of an application and issuance of an alarm system permit. The fee shall not exceed $25.00 per year and shall be nonrefundable whether or not a permit is issued. 
(c)  Each permit shall be effective on the date issued and shall remain in effect for one year from the date issued unless revoked pursuant to provisions of this article. The chief of police shall notify each permit holder that his permit must be renewed at least 45 days prior to its date of expiration by mailing a written notice to each such permit holder at the address listed on the permit application. 
(d)  If the applicant is an individual, the application shall be signed and verified by the applicant. If the applicant is a partnership, the application shall be signed and verified by at least one of its general partners. If the application is a corporation or other entity, the application shall be signed and verified by the president of such corporation or entity or other agent authorized to sign on behalf of the corporation. 
(e)  The applicant shall be responsible for: 
(1)  The proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system; 
(2)  Payment of the fees assessed under this article; and 
(3)  Responding within a reasonable time, in person or by agent, to the alarm site, if requested by and upon receiving notification from the police department in response to an alarm system activation. Thirty minutes after receiving said police department notification shall be deemed a reasonable time period for responding to the alarm site. 
(f)  An alarm permit under this article cannot be transferred to another person or entity. 
(g)  The applicant shall verify that the information contained in the application is true and correct, and that the applicant has read the provisions of this article, fully understands the provisions thereof, and is and shall remain in compliance therewith. 
(h)  The permit application shall include: 
(1)  The applicant's full legal name, including any and all other names by which the applicant has been known; 
(2)  If the applicant is a corporation, the exact corporate name, state of incorporation, and the name of its chief executive officer; 
(3)  The current residence address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(4)  A telephone number at the site of the alarm system; 
(5)  The address and legal description of the parcel of land on which the alarm system is located, and any business name or title used for the alarm site; 
(6)  Written proof that the applicant is at least 17 years of age; 
(7)  The name, address, and telephone number of the individual or business monitoring the alarm system; 
(8)  The name, address, and telephone number of at least one person whom the applicant has designated to respond to the alarm site on notification from the police department in response to an alarm system activation; and 
(9)  Such additional information as determined by the chief of police as necessary or desirable to accomplish the purpose and intent of this article. 
(i)  The permit holder shall not be required to pay a permit fee for renewal of a permit if the premises for which the permit is applicable have not had a false alarm notification during the preceding 12 months. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-71, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-127. - Issuance or denial of permit. 
(a)  The chief of police shall conduct an investigation relating to the permit application. Based on such investigation, the chief of police shall approve or deny a permit. 
(b)  Within 45 days after receipt of the application for permit, the chief of police shall inform the applicant by regular mail as to the approval or denial of said permit. 
(c)  A temporary permit may be issued upon application, but such temporary permit shall expire on the date the permit applied for is either approved or denied. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-72, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 2005-13, § 1, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 82-128. - Grounds for denial of permit. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue a permit to the applicant unless one or more of the following conditions exists: 
(1)  The applicant fails to provide all of the information requested on the application or otherwise submits an incomplete application; 
(2)  The applicant gives false, misleading, or untruthful information of material fact on the application; 
(3)  The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, this article or city building, zoning, or health regulations; 
(4)  The applicant, whether he is an individual, a corporate agent, an officer or director, a partner, a manager, or any persons principally in charge of the premises where the alarm system is located, is not 17 years of age or older; 
(5)  The alarm system has a history of unreliability and the applicant has failed to make alterations or corrections to the system that reasonably assure abatement of false alarms. Any alarm system generating either ten false burglary alarm notifications or five false robbery alarm notifications within a 12-consecutive-month period shall be presumed unreliable; 
(6)  The applicant has failed to pay a fee assessed pursuant to this article that has become due; or 
(7)  The application or the site of the alarm system does not meet all of the other requirements of this article. 
(b)  Denial of an alarm system permit shall be effected by written notice thereof, setting forth the grounds therefor, to the applicant, sent by regular mail at the direction of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-72(a), 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 2005-13, § 1, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 82-129. - Grounds for revocation of permit. 
(a)  The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a permit issued under this article when: 
(1)  The permit holder or his designated agent has entered or given false, misleading, or untruthful information of material fact in any record or report required by this article; 
(2)  The permit holder fails to pay any assessed false alarm service fees within 30 days from the date they first become due and payable; 
(3)  The permit holder or his designated agent fails to arrive at the alarm site within a reasonable time, usually not to exceed 30 minutes after said individual has been notified by the police department that the permit holder's alarm system is transmitting an alarm signal; 
(4)  The permit holder fails to maintain the alarm system or alarm site in accordance with this article; or 
(5)  The operation of the alarm system by the permit holder has accrued a demonstrated history of unreliability. 
(b)  Permits revoked under this article shall become invalid on 30 days' written notice of termination mailed by the police department to the permit holder. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-72(b), 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-130. - False alarm notifications; service fee. 
(a)  After the police department responds to three false burglary alarm notifications from one alarm site within any consecutive 12-month period, the permit holder shall be assessed by the chief of police a fee in the amount of $50.00 for each additional false burglary alarm notification responded to by the police department thereafter. 
(b)  After the police department responds to ten false burglary alarm notifications from one alarm site within any consecutive 12-month period, the chief of police may, in addition to the assessment of fees as provided in this article, revoke the alarm permit on grounds that the alarm system has a demonstrated history of unreliability. 
(c)  After the police department responds to two false robbery alarm notifications from one alarm site within any consecutive 12-month period, the permit holder shall be assessed by the chief of police a fee in the amount of $100.00 for each additional false robbery alarm notification responded to by the police department thereafter. 
(d)  After the police department responds to five false robbery alarm notifications from one alarm site within any consecutive 12-month period, the chief of police may, in addition to the assessment of fees as provided in this article, revoke the alarm permit on grounds that the alarm system has a demonstrated history of unreliability. 
(e)  An applicant shall pay any and all fees assessed under this article before an alarm system permit may be issued or reinstated, if previously revoked. A reinstatement fee of $50.00 will be assessed on reinstatement of a previously revoked permit. 
(f)  False alarm notifications resulting from a common cause shall be counted as a single false alarm if the false alarm notifications occur within a 72-consecutive-hour period, action is taken to rectify the common cause, such action is documented to the police department, and a period of 30 consecutive days follows the last false alarm notification without another false alarm notification resulting from that documented cause. 
(g)  The chief of police may notify the permit holder by regular mail that such permit holder has accumulated a sufficient number of false alarm notifications at an alarm site within a consecutive 12-month period to subject his permit to revocation and, in addition, may give notice of the revocation of the alarm system permit. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-73, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 2005-13, § 1, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 82-131. - Exemptions. 
    The following are specifically exempt from the application and enforcement of all provisions of this article: 
(1)  An alarm system installed on a vehicle, unless such vehicle is used for a habitation at a permanent site. 
(2)  Other types of alarm systems which are not intended to transmit or relay a signal designed to summon the police department to respond to a burglary or robbery, including, but not limited to fire alarms, alarm systems installed and used for bona fide medical emergencies, and alarm systems that monitor temperature, humidity, or any other conditions not directly related to the detection of a burglary or a robbery on the premises. 
(3)  Alarm systems installed on the interior of a structure for the sole purpose and function of alerting only the occupants of the premises where the alarm system is installed, but only if such alarm notification cannot be heard outside the structure where the alarm system is installed. 
(4)  Alarm systems installed upon premises occupied by local, state, or federal government authorities, or any of their bona fide agencies. 
(5)  False alarm notifications caused by vandalism, severe weather that causes physical damage to the alarm site or activates the alarm, telephone line outage, attempted unauthorized entry onto the premises, or a natural or manmade catastrophe. 
(6)  False alarm notifications due to a chronic electrical or mechanical problem which the permit holder is working diligently to correct, if such permit holder provides the chief of police with a written statement from the company which installed the alarm system indicating the nature of the problem, what efforts are being made to correct the problem, and when the company anticipates the problem being resolved. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-74, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-132. - Automatic dialing devices. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any automatic dialing device which, when activated, uses a telephone device or attachment to automatically select a telephone line leading into the police department or other office of the city and then transmits any prerecorded message or signal. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-75, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-133. - Indirect alarm notification reporting. 
    Any person engaged in the business of relaying alarm notifications to the city or police department must do so in compliance with all laws, including the Private Investigators and Private Security Agencies Act, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1702.001 et seq., and shall report alarm notifications in a manner and form as may be required by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-76, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-134. - Alarm dispatch records. 
(a)  Upon receiving an alarm notification of a burglary or robbery, the police department may record such information as the chief of police or his designee deems necessary or desirable, which should include the following: 
(1)  Verification of the permit and identification of the permit holder; 
(2)  Identification of the alarm site; 
(3)  The time dispatch is received and officer arrival time; 
(4)  The date; 
(5)  Weather conditions, if applicable; 
(6)  The name of permit holder's representative on premises, if any; and 
(7)  The response time of the representative to the alarm site after notification by the police department. 
(b)  The responding police officer should indicate on the dispatch record the apparent cause of the alarm notification, as determined from an inspection of the interior or exterior of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-77, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-135. - Duplication of permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to counterfeit, forge, change, deface, or in any manner alter a permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-78, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 82-136. - Permit required. 
(a)  Any person who operates an alarm system in violation of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $500.00. Each day of such operation shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  In addition to any criminal penalties herein described, the city attorney's office is hereby authorized to file suit to enjoin the violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-38, § 18-79, 9-7-2004) 
Secs. 82-137-82-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CURFEW REGULATIONS FOR MINORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Review of curfew every three years, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 370.002; children taken into custody for violation of curfew, V.T.C.A., Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.059. 

Sec. 82-156. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article sets forth regulations for the conduct of minors on streets at night. These regulations encompass prevailing community standards for the purpose of furthering the good of minors, of advancing family responsibility and of promoting public safety and welfare. The city commission has determined that the curfew meets a very real need and is a significant factor in minimizing juvenile delinquency. The city commission also finds that commercial recreational facilities are very limited in the city. The curfew hours established by this article reflect the community standard of the appropriate hour for cessation of outdoor activities by minors on the street. The curfew also takes into account the hours which present the highest risk for nocturnal crimes and for the congregating of minors with potential risks incident to immaturity. Therefore, the city commission finds that this article is necessary and that it serves the community's intent in protecting our minors from criminal and other unhealthy influences. The city commission has determined that parental responsibility for the whereabouts of minors is a community norm. As parental control increases, the likelihood of juvenile delinquency decreases. Therefore, legal sanctions to enforce parental responsibility have shown to be significantly effective in minimizing the incidence of juvenile delinquency. The city commission hereby determines that the curfew for minors will accomplish under local conditions the purposes stated herein. 
(Code 1969, § 18-80; Ord. No. 87-20, § 1, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-157. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Minor means any person under the age of 17 years. 
    Motor vehicle means every mechanical device in, upon, or by which any person or property is to be transported or drawn upon a public highway, including, but not limited to, motorcycles, cars, pickup trucks, tractors, semitrailers, trailers, vans, motor scooters, mopeds, truck tractors and bicycles. 
    Parent means any person having legal custody of a minor as: 
(1)  A natural or adoptive parent; 
(2)  A legal guardian; 
(3)  A person who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)  A person to whom legal custody has been given by order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
    Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets, including, but not limited to, the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) in which any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes, such as mere passage or going home. Within this meaning, this article does not prohibit mere presence but is intended to prohibit "remaining." 
    Street means a way or place, of whatever nature, opened to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel, or, in the case of a sidewalk thereof, for pedestrian travel. The term "street" includes the legal right-of-way, including, but not limited to, the traffic lanes, curbs, sidewalks, whether paved or unpaved, and any grass plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-way of the street. The term "street" applies irrespective of what it may be called or informally named, whether alley, avenue, road, roadway, highway or otherwise. 
    Time of night means the prevailing standard of time, whether Central Standard Time or Central Daylight Saving Time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city. It shall be prima facie the time then observed in the city administrative offices and police station. 
(Code 1969, § 18-81; Ord. No. 87-20, § 2, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-158. - Curfew hours for minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under 17 years of age to be or remain in or upon the streets within the city at night during the period beginning at 11:00 p.m. and ending at 6:00 a.m., Sunday through Thursday, and beginning at 12:00 midnight and ending at 6:00 a.m., Friday and Saturday. The provisions of this section will also apply to any person under 17 years of age that may be in a motor vehicle, unless exempted under section 82-159(a)(7). 
(Code 1969, § 18-82; Ord. No. 87-20, § 3, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-159. - Defense to accusation of unlawful conduct. 
(a)  It shall be a defense to the accusation of unlawful conduct pursuant to section 82-158 for the accused minor to demonstrate that he was: 
(1)  Accompanied by a parent or the adult spouse of such minor. 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. 
(3)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. Prior to engaging in the exercise of such First Amendment rights at a time that would otherwise be in violation of this article, such minor shall first deliver a written communication, signed by such minor and countersigned, if practicable, by a parent of such a minor with their home address and telephone number to the police chief of the city, or to the officer assigned by him on duty, specifying when, where and in what manner said minor will be on the streets at night (during hours when the provisions of this article are otherwise applicable to said minor), in the exercise of a First Amendment right specified in such communication. 
(4)  Returning home, by a direct route, from a school activity or an activity of a religious or other voluntary association of which prior notice, indicating the place and probable time of termination, has been given in writing to, and duly filed for immediate reference by, the chief of police or the officer assigned by him on duty at the police station, thus encouraging (here as in other exceptional situations) conduct on the part of minor involved in such activities a fair balance for the conflicting interest of the minor and the interest of the city in regulating the behavior of such minor. 
(5)  Engaged in nighttime activities organized by the schools and attracting more minors than can readily be dealt with on an individual, special permit basis. In such cases, such nighttime activity shall have been organized by or through the schools or other similar organization in a regular course. 
(6)  In possession of a certified card of employment, renewable each calendar month, dated or reissued not more than 45 days previously, signed by the employer and the chief of police and briefly identifying the minor, the addresses of his home and of his place of employment and his hours of employment. Possession of said certified card shall be sufficient to exempt such minor from the restrictions of this article, if such minor was, in fact, engaged in or traveling to or from such employment in accordance with the hours as indicated by such certified card. 
(7)  Involved in interstate or intrastate motor vehicle travel, with parental consent. This section specifically exempts interstate travel beginning or ending in the city. This section does not exempt motor vehicle travel merely in or around the city. 
(b)  Each of the foregoing exceptions and the several limitations, such as provisions for notification, are severable as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1969, § 18-83; Ord. No. 87-20, § 4, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-160. - Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a minor knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to allow such minor to be or remain upon any city street under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise outside the scope of, this article. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge that a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It shall be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct of whereabouts of such minor. 
(Code 1969, § 18-84; Ord. No. 87-20, § 5, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-161. - Police procedures. 
(a)  A police officer of the city, upon finding or having attention called to any minor on the streets in prima facie violation of this article, should follow the complete police department juvenile procedures, insofar as those procedures have been approved by the Hidalgo County Juvenile Court(s). In the absence of convincing evidence, such as a birth certificate, a police officer on the street shall, on the first instance, use his best judgment in determining age. In following the police department juvenile procedures, a police officer must act in accordance with the state family code as it is now enacted or may be hereafter amended. In the case of the first violation by a minor, the juvenile officer or other designated police officer shall send to a parent written notice of said violation, certified mail, with a warning that any subsequent violation may result in the enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(b)  The prohibition enacted by this article shall apply only to juveniles as defined by the V.T.C.A., Family Code § 51.01 et seq. If a police officer takes into custody, for violation of this article, a minor who is discovered to be under the age of ten years old, such minor shall not therefor be accused of unlawful conduct pursuant to this article. Instead, the officer is to release such minor to his parent, guardian, custodian or other responsible adult as soon as practicable, pursuant to the police department juvenile procedures. This subsection shall not be construed as a defense to prosecution of the parent of such minor charged with an offense under section 82-160. 
(Code 1969, § 18-85; Ord. No. 87-20, § 6, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-162. - Violations, penalties. 
    If, after notice pursuant to section 82-161 of a first violation by a minor, a parent violates section 82-160 (in connection with a second violation by said minor), this shall be treated as a first offense by the parent. Upon conviction for such first parental offense, a parent may be fined in an amount not to exceed $100.00. Upon conviction for a subsequent offense of violation of this article, the parent may be fined in an amount no more than $200.00 for each such subsequent conviction. 
(Code 1969, § 18-86; Ord. No. 87-20, § 7, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 82-163. - Referral. 
    Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of this article more than two times may be referred by the juvenile officer to the county juvenile probation department for processing as a child having engaged in conduct indicating a need for supervision. In making any such referral, the juvenile officer shall follow the appropriate police department juvenile procedures. 
(Code 1969, § 18-87; Ord. No. 87-20, § 8, 6-16-1987) 
Secs. 82-164-82-194. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GRAFFITI 

Sec. 82-195. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aerosol paint container means any aerosol container that is adopted or made for the purpose of applying aerosolized paint products or other substances capable of defacing property. 
    Consent means assent, in fact, expressed or apparent, by a person legally authorized to act for the owner. 
    Etching equipment means any tool, device or surface that can be used to make permanent marks on any natural or manmade surface. 
    Felt-tip marker means any felt-tip marker or similar implement with a flat or angled writing surface that, at its broadest width, is one-fourth inch or greater, containing ink or other liquid that is not water soluble and this is specifically formulated to be more difficult to erase, wash out, or remove than ordinary paint or ink products. 
    Graffiti means any inscription, word, letter, figure, painting, drawing, mark or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface or public or private property without advance consent of the owner, or is otherwise a public nuisance. 
    Graffiti implement means an aerosol paint container, paint gun, paintball gun, felt-tip marker, paint, stick or graffiti stick, brush, or etching tool or etching device capable of scarring, marking or otherwise defacing glass, metal, concrete, wood or any other surface. 
    Minor means any person under 17 years of age. 
    Owner means any person who has title to the property or a legal right to control the property, including the owner's authorized representative. 
    Paint stick or graffiti stick means any device containing a solid form of paint, chalk, wax, epoxy, or other similar substance capable of being applied to a surface by pressure and leaving a visible mark. 
    Parent means a person having legal custody of a minor, such as: 
(1)  A natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent; 
(2)  A legal guardian; 
(3)  A person who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)  A person to whom legal custody has been given by the court. 
    Real property means any land or residential property owned by a parent or guardian. 
(Code 1969, § 18-90; Ord. No. 97-09, § 2, 9-2-1997) 
Sec. 82-196. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to apply graffiti to public or private property without the permission of the owner. This provision is intended to supplement and not conflict with V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.03. 
(b)  Possession of graffiti implement. It shall be unlawful for a minor to possess any graffiti implement on public or private property without the prior consent of the owner.
