    When, in the opinion of the city commission, the necessities of commerce require such, a loading zone may be designated by ordinance along a single parking space or section of the curb and adjacent street, which loading zone shall be set aside for the exclusive use of loading or unloading of persons, merchandise, supplies and materials. A charge of $60.00 per year shall be paid to the city for each parking space so designated as a loading zone. 
(Code 1969, § 27-79; Ord. No. 69-18, § 8, 5-6-1969) 
Sec. 134-138. - Same-Designation, use by merchants, others. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to designate a delivery zone to any merchant actually engaged in a delivery business. 
(b)  No delivery zone shall be issued to any person or merchant whose business building actually abuts or opens on to a public alley or easement, or who has access to a public alley or easement from his place of business. 
(c)  No vehicle shall park, stand, or stop in a delivery zone except that vehicle utilized in the delivery business. Such vehicle shall be plainly marked on the outside of both sides with letters not smaller than two inches in size stating the name of the business. 
(Code 1969, § 27-79.1; Ord. No. 69-18, § 8, 5-6-1969) 
Sec. 134-139. - Same-Marking. 
    Where the city commission has authorized loading zones, the parking spaces shall be marked by the city manager, or under his direction, and the words "Loading Zone" shall be painted on the curb adjacent to such zone. 
(Code 1969, § 27-80; Ord. No. 69-18, § 8, 5-6-1969) 
Sec. 134-140. - Same-Parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator to park a vehicle in a loading zone for a period in excess of 30 minutes unless loading or unloading operations are continuously in progress during such excessive time. 
(Code 1969, § 27-81; Ord. No. 69-18, § 8, 5-6-1969) 
Sec. 134-141. - Reserved. 
Sec. 134-142. - Parking lot pavement markings. 
    In all residential and commercial parking lots where more than two off-street parking spaces are required, the following colors shall be used for pavement markings: 
(1)  White. The color white shall be used to designate parking spaces; 
(2)  Yellow. The color yellow shall be used to designate "No Parking Areas" and loading zones; and 
(3)  Red. The color red shall be used to designate fire lanes. 
(Code 1969, § 27-83; Ord. No. 86-27, § 2, 7-15-1986) 
Sec. 134-143. - Residential truck parking requirements. 
    The parking, storing or otherwise stationing of truck-tractors, trailers, pole-trailers, semitrailers, house trailers, and trucks (exceeding 30 feet in length) on public rights-of-way, or in improved or unimproved lots, as defined by chapter 150 and specified by the city zoning map, is prohibited. Parking of truck-tractors, trailers, pole-trailers, semitrailers, house trailers, and trucks (exceeding 30 feet in length) in commercial or industrial zones shall be permitted and shall be in accordance with article VI of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 27-84; Ord. No. 90-24, § 2, 10-16-1990; Ord. No. 98-09, § 1, 6-16-1998) 
Secs. 134-144-134-234. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED PARKING FOR THE DISABLED 

Sec. 134-235. - Designation of spaces or areas; definition; authority of police chief; signs required. 
    The chief of police is hereby granted authority to designate parking spaces or parking areas specifically for the temporarily or permanently disabled. A person is disabled who has a mobility problem that substantially impairs his ability to ambulate, or who is legally blind. Any space so designated by the chief of police shall meet the minimum requirements for parking spaces specifically designated for disabled persons, as promulgated by the state department of highways and public transportation, and shall likewise be marked with a sign of the type approved by the state department of highways and public transportation, such sign also being located in accordance with the regulations of such department. 
(Code 1969, § 27-159; Ord. No. 82-20, § 1, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 134-236. - Authority of property owner to designate parking spaces. 
    Any person who owns or controls property used for parking may likewise designate one or more parking spaces or a parking area for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting temporarily or permanently disabled persons, providing that such person shall designate such space or area by posting in a conspicuous place a sign that conforms with the design and posting requirements of this article and state law. 
(Code 1969, § 27-160; Ord. No. 82-20, § 2, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 134-237. - Posting of signs. 
    The chief of police shall post a sign that conforms with design and posting requirements of state law, at each access or curb ramp designed for the use of temporarily or permanently disabled persons, on a public street. 
(Code 1969, § 27-161; Ord. No. 82-20, § 3, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 134-238. - Offenses. 
(a)  Unauthorized use of emblem or device. A person commits an offense if a person is neither temporarily nor permanently disabled nor transporting a temporarily or permanently disabled person and parks a vehicle displaying a disabled device or emblem approved by the state department of highways and public transportation or the similar department of any other state, or displays a temporarily disabled person identification card, in any parking space or parking area designated specifically for the disabled, whether such area is on a public street or has been so designated by a private property owner. 
(b)  Parking of unauthorized vehicle in reserved space. A person likewise commits an offense if he parks a vehicle neither displaying the special device nor displaying a temporarily disabled person identification card in a parking space or parking area designated specifically for the disabled. The special device or temporarily disabled person identification card referred to in this subsection shall mean a special device or identification card issued by the state department of highways and public transportation or a similar agency of any other state. 
(c)  Obstructing access of disabled. A person commits an offense if he parks a vehicle so that the vehicle blocks an access or curb ramp or any other architectural improvement designed to aid the disabled. 
(Code 1969, § 27-162; Ord. No. 82-20, §§ 4-6, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 134-239. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the terms and provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $200.00. 
(Code 1969, § 27-163; Ord. No. 82-20, § 7, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 134-240. - Enforcement persons. 
(a)  The chief of police or his designee shall have the authority to appoint any qualified person who is a citizen of the United States, is a resident of the city, is of good moral character, and who has not previously been convicted of a felony, to enforce the provisions of Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotation, article 6675a-5e.1 in the city. 
(b)  Each person appointed pursuant to this section shall complete an application and satisfactorily complete a course of training on disabled parking enforcement. 
(c)  The application required by subsection (b) of this section shall show the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the immediate members of the family of the applicant, the applicant's marital status, and shall have attached thereto a photograph of the applicant, together with sufficient fingerprints to definitely identify the applicant. The chief of police or his designee is specifically authorized to require additional information from the applicant. Upon receipt of the application, the chief of police or his designee shall cause a complete and thorough investigation to be made of the applicant to determine his moral, physical and mental qualifications. 
(d)  Any qualified persons so appointed shall have the power to serve citations for violations for failure to comply with the Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotation, article 6675a-5e.1 in the same manner as any law enforcement officer of the state or county or municipality of the state, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  No person appointed shall be deemed a peace officer, nor an employee of the state, the county or the city, nor receive any compensation therefrom. 
(2)  No appointed person shall be required to complete training as a peace officer. 
(3)  No appointed person shall have the power or duty to enforce other traffic or criminal laws. 
(4)  No appointed person shall possess or carry firearms or other weapons for the purpose of enforcing the disabled parking law. 
(5)  No appointed person shall be entitled to any indemnification from the state, the county, or the city for any injury or property damage sustained as a result of enforcement activities; each appointed person shall specifically acknowledge that such person has no rights to any claim of injury or property damage resulting from disabled parking enforcement activities. 
(6)  No government, agency, department or officer of the state, the county or city shall be liable or accountable for any act or omission of any person appointed to issue disabled parking citations pursuant to this section. Each authorized person shall specifically hold harmless the city, its employees, officers, and agents, from liability for any such act or omission by such authorized person. 
(Code 1969, § 27-164; Ord. No. 94-04, §§ 1-4, 2-15-1994) 
Secs. 134-241-134-258. - Reserved.

(28)  Pleasantview Drive from Interstate 2 to US Business 83; 
(29)  Calle De La Republica from Interstate 2 to Pike Boulevard. 
(30)  Bridge Avenue from Business Highway 83 to Witmer Street. 
(Code 1969, § 27-172; Ord. No. 84-43, § 1, 11-6-1984; Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 9-7-1999; Ord. No. 2016-26, §§ I, II, 8-2-2016; Ord. No. 2017-05, § II, 2-14-2017) 
Sec. 134-260. - Penalty for violation. 
    All owners, operators or persons in control of trucks, semitrailers or truck tractors driving on streets, roads or boulevards other than the above-described streets, roads or boulevards shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than $1.00 or more than $200.00. 
(Code 1969, § 27-173; Ord. No. 84-43, § 3, 11-6-1984) 
Secs. 134-261-134-283. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING SPACES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of loads and equipment, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 621.303. 

Sec. 134-284. - Required; when. 
    In order to provide for the safety and general welfare of the community, there shall be provided at the time any building or structure is erected or structurally altered, off-street parking spaces in accordance with the minimum requirements provided in this article. These requirements have been designed to lessen the congestion in the streets and facilitate the adequate transportation of both emergency and normal vehicular traffic. All parking spaces shall be provided on private property unless otherwise stated. 
(Code 1969, § 27-181; Ord. No. 89-6, § 1, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-285. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central business district means the area located between Pike Boulevard and Sixth Street and between the alley east of Kansas Avenue and the alley west of Missouri Avenue. Any existing building located within this district are not required to provide off-street parking as long as its use remains for commercial activity only. New construction must comply with this article. 
    Loading space means a space within the main building or on the same lot therewith provided for the standing, loading or unloading of trucks, or other service vehicles and having minimum dimensions of 12 by 60 feet for industrial and warehouse uses and 12 by 35 feet for commercial and institutional uses within a vertical clearance of at least 14 feet, together with access and maneuvering areas, provided on the same building lot as the principal use for which the loading space is intended. 
    Parking space means an area on a lot enclosed or unenclosed, as specified herein, exclusive of the driveways connecting such space with a street or alley. Such parking space and connecting driveway shall be durably surfaced in accordance with section 134-291 and so arranged as to permit satisfactory ingress and egress of an automobile, as set out in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 27-182; Ord. No. 89-6, § 2, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-286. - Parking requirements based on use. 
    In all districts there shall be provided, at the time a building or structure is erected or structurally altered, off-street parking spaces in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Bowling alley: six parking spaces for each lane. 
(2)  Business or professional office, studio, bank, medical or dental clinic: three parking spaces plus one additional parking space for each 200 square feet of floor area over 500 feet. 
(3)  Church or other place of worship: one parking space for each four seats in the main auditorium. 
(4)  Commercial development within the central business district: 
a.  No off-street parking spaces are required if business is established within an existing building. 
b.  If a new building is constructed, then off-street parking must be provided as specified in this article. 
(5)  Commercial development both inside and outside of central business district over 10,000 square feet and institutional uses: For buildings containing over 10,000 square feet, a separate parking plan must be submitted, such plan to specifically show the following: 
a.  Number of spaces, ratio of space to floor area, and dimensions. 
b.  Driveway locations and driveway sizes. 
c.  On-site traffic control, i.e., directional driveways, traffic-control islands, handling of merging traffic and other methods and devices to show the parking area will effectively handle the volume of cars at peak parking periods. 
d.  A study showing the public rights-of-way abutting the parking area and onto which the driveways will be emptying, and the capability of such rights-of-way to handle the added traffic loads imposed by the parking being provided. 
e.  On-site parking illumination shall be required and shall be determined at two footcandles' minimum illumination on all parking surfaces. 
(6)  Library, museum or art gallery: ten parking spaces plus one additional space for each 300 square feet of floor area in excess of 2,000 square feet. If an auditorium is included as a part of the building, its floor area shall be deducted from the total and additional parking provided on the basis of one space for each four seats it contains. 
(7)  Dance hall, assembly, community center or exhibition hall without fixed seats: three parking spaces for each 100 square feet of floor area thereof. 
(8)  Dwellings, single-family attached or detached: two parking spaces for each dwelling unit; provided that where the lot was subdivided prior to the current minimum lot sizes and where the lot has less than 50 feet of frontage and contains less than 6,000 square feet, an exception may be granted to allow one parking space per dwelling. 
(9)  Dwelling, multifamily: one parking space for each dwelling unit, plus one-half space for each individual bedroom in all dwelling units. Two parking spaces shall be required for each one bedroom dwelling unit in complexes where there are five dwelling units or less. 
(10)  Fraternity, sorority or dormitory: one parking space for each two beds. 
(11)  Furniture or appliance store, hardware store, wholesale establishments, machinery or equipment sales and service, clothing or shoe repair or service: two parking spaces for each 300 square feet plus one additional parking space for each 300 square feet of floor area over 1,000 square feet. 
(12)  Hospital: one-half space per employee on the largest shift, plus one space per bed per patient room. 
(13)  Hotel, motel, bed and breakfast: one parking space for one sleeping room or suite plus one space for each 200 square feet of commercial floor area contained therein. 
(14)  Manufacturing or industrial establishment, research or testing laboratory, creamery, bottling plant, canning plant, packing shed, warehouse, printing or plumbing shop, or similar establishment: one parking space for each employee on the maximum working shift plus space to accommodate all trucks and other vehicles used in connection therewith, but not less than one parking space for each 1,000 square feet of floor area. 
(15)  Mobile home park: two spaces for each mobile home plus additional spaces as required herein for accessory uses. Cars may park in tandem, subject to the provisions of sections 86-29-86-37. 
(16)  Mortuary or funeral home: one parking space for each 50 square feet of floor space in slumber rooms, parlors or individual funeral service rooms. 
(17)  Motor vehicle salesrooms and used car lots: one parking space for each 500 square feet of display area for indoor uses, or one parking space for each 1,000 square feet of lot area for outdoor uses. 
(18)  Private club, lodge, country club or golf club: one parking space for each 150 square feet of floor area or for every five members, whichever is greater. 
(19)  Retail store or personal store or personal service establishment, except as otherwise specified herein: one parking space per 200 square feet, plus an additional space shall be required for each employee. 
(20)  Restaurant, night club, cafe or similar recreation or amusement establishment: one parking space for each 100 square feet of service floor area, excluding the kitchen, storage, restroom and hallways, plus one space per employee. 
(21)  Roominghouse or boardinghouse: one parking space for each two beds. 
(22)  Sanitarium, convalescent home, home for the aged or similar institution: one parking space for each six beds, plus one additional space per employee. 
(23)  School, elementary and middle: one parking space for each three seats in the auditorium or main assembly room, or two spaces for each classroom or one space per employee on the maximum on-campus shift, whichever is greater. 
(24)  School, secondary and college: one parking space for each four seats in the main auditorium or eight spaces for each classroom, whichever is greater. 
(25)  Theater, auditorium (except school), sports arena, stadium, gymnasium or special use building with fixed seats: one parking space for each four seats or bench seating spaces. 
(26)  Townhouse, condominium or garden home: two parking spaces per dwelling unit. 
(27)  Other: Any unlisted nonresidential use shall provide off-street parking adequate to accommodate the normal parking demand generated by such use. 
(Code 1969, § 27-183; Ord. No. 89-6, § 3, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-287. - Rules for computing number of parking spaces. 
    In computing the number of parking spaces required for each of the above uses the following rules shall govern: 
(1)  For the purposes of this section, the term "floor area" shall mean the actual area used instead of gross floor area. 
(2)  Where fractional spaces result, the parking spaces required shall be construed to be the nearest whole number. 
(3)  The parking space requirement for a use not specifically mentioned herein shall be the same as required for a use of similar nature. 
(4)  Whenever a building or use constructed or established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived is changed or enlarged in floor area, number of employees, number of dwelling units, seating capacity or otherwise, to create a need for an increase of ten percent or more in the number of existing parking spaces, such spaces shall be provided on the basis of the enlargement or change. Whenever a building or use existing prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived is enlarged to the extent of 50 percent or more in floor area or in the area used, such building or use shall then and thereafter comply with the parking requirements set forth herein. 
(5)  In the case of mixed uses, the parking spaces required shall equal the sum of the requirements of the various uses computed separately, except in cases where the mixed use is not open to the public and the intent is not to generate additional traffic, such mixed use shall not be counted separately. 
(6)  Where parking spaces and loading zones are provided, the number to be reserved for the handicapped shall be in accordance with article IV of this chapter and the currently adopted Southern Standard Building Codes. 
(Code 1969, § 27-184; Ord. No. 89-6, § 4, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-288. - Location of parking spaces. 
    All parking spaces required herein shall be located on the same lot with the building or use served, except as follows: 
(1)  Where an increase in the number of spaces is required by a change or enlargement of use of where such spaces are provided collectively or used jointly by two or more buildings or establishments, the required spaces may be located not to exceed 300 feet from an institutional building served and not exceed 500 feet from any other nonresidential building served. 
(2)  Not more than 50 percent of the parking spaces required for theaters, bowling alleys, dance halls, night clubs, cafes or similar uses and not more than 80 percent of the parking spaces required for a church or school auditorium or similar uses may be provided and used jointly by banks, offices, retail stores, repair shops, service establishments and similar uses not normally open, used or operated during the same hours as those listed above; provided, however, that written agreement thereto is properly executed and filed as specified in this section. 
(3)  In any case where the required parking spaces are not located on the same lot with the building or use served or where such spaces are collectively or jointly provided and used, a written agreement thereby assuring their retention for such purposes, shall be properly drawn and executed by the parties concerned, approved as to form by the city attorney and executed by the parties concerned and shall be filed with the application for a building permit. 
(4)  Where the parking space abuts the property line, wheel stops shall be provided and maintained to prohibit vehicle encroachment over the property line. 
(5)  No parking, wall, fence, sign, structure, or natural plant material with a height in excess of three feet above the crown of the nearest street will be permitted in a triangle formed by measuring a distance of 30 feet along the front and side lot lines, from their point of intersection, and connecting the points so that they form a triangle on the area of the lot adjacent to the street intersection. 
(Code 1969, § 27-185; Ord. No. 89-6, § 5, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-289. - Off-street loading space. 
    Every building or part thereof erected or occupied for retail business, service, manufacturing, storage, warehousing, hotel, mortuary or any other use similarly involving the receipt or distribution by vehicles of materials or merchandise, shall provide and maintain on the same premises loading space in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Loading spaces shall meet the minimum size requirement as outlined in section 134-286. Parking area shall be of the size of the length of one loading space squared. Loading space and parking maneuvering area shall be of a measurement equal to the width of the loading space or parking area and the length of a loading space beginning from where the loading space or parking ends (see Exhibit "A" to the ordinance from which this article is derived, which is on file in the office of the city secretary). 
(2)  The provisions of section 134-286 and this section shall apply to existing and established industry when the following occurs: when any new additional or structural change occurs to an existing building. If the structural change or addition is valued at or is more than 50 percent of the building's taxable value then the entire building must comply with the existing application codes and ordinances, as amended. If the structural change or addition is valued at less than 50 percent of the building's taxable value, then only the addition or the structural change must comply with the existing applicable codes and ordinances, as amended. 
(3)  All loading spaces shall be located on site, and no loading spaces shall be located in a designated fire lane. 
(Code 1969, § 27-186; Ord. No. 89-6, § 6, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-290. - Minimum dimensions for off-street parking. 
(a)  Ninety-degree angle parking. Each parking space shall be not less than nine feet wide nor less than 18 feet in length. Maneuvering space shall be in addition to parking space and shall be not less than 24 feet perpendicular to the building or parking line. 
(b)  Sixty-degree angle parking. Each parking space shall be not less than nine feet wide perpendicular to the parking angle nor less than 18 feet in length when measured at right angles to the building or parking line. Maneuvering space shall be in addition to parking space and shall be not less than 20 feet perpendicular to the building or parking line. 
(c)  Forty-five-degree angle parking. Each parking space shall be not less than nine feet wide perpendicular to the parking angle nor less than 18 feet in length when measured at right angles to the building or parking line. Maneuvering space shall be in addition to parking line. 
(d)  Other. When off-street parking facilities are located adjacent to a public alley, the width of such alley may be assumed to be a portion of the maneuvering space requirement. Where off-street parking facilities are provided in excess of the minimum amounts herein specified or when off-street parking facilities are provided but not required by this article, such off-street parking facilities shall comply with the minimum requirements for parking and maneuvering space herein specified. 
(Code 1969, § 27-187; Ord. No. 89-6, § 7, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-291. - Standards for paving off-street parking spaces. 
    All parking lots provided in the city shall be paved and sealed in accordance with municipal specifications. All private parking shall be constructed of either a concrete or asphalt surface. Minimum construction requirements for commercial, institutional, multifamily and single-family shall be six-inch caliche base and 125 pounds per square yard asphalt surface or standard concrete at 2,500 pounds per square inch. Minimum construction requirements for industrial uses shall be eight-inch caliche base and 150 pounds per eight-inch square yard or eight-inch reenforced concrete. 
(Code 1969, § 27-188; Ord. No. 89-6, § 8, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-292. - Width of entrances and exits. 
(a)  One-way commercial driveways (entrance or exit) shall be a minimum of 12 feet and a maximum of 25 feet wide at the property line. 
(b)  Two-way commercial driveways (entrance and exit) shall be a minimum of 25 feet and a maximum of 45 feet wide at the property line. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, § 9, 2-7-1989; Ord. No. 2007-54, § III, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 134-293. - Variance procedures. 
    Request for a variance from any sections of this article shall be in accordance with section 150-19. 
(Code 1969, § 27-190; Ord. No. 89-6, § 10, 2-7-1989) 
Sec. 134-294. - Resolution of conflict. 
    Whenever the standards and specifications in this article conflict with those contained in another ordinance, the most stringent or restrictive provision shall govern. 
(Code 1969, § 27-191; Ord. No. 89-6, § 11, 2-7-1989) 
ARTICLE VII. - VULNERABLE ROAD USERS 

Sec. 134-295. - Authority; area. 
(a)  The City of Weslaco hereby adopts and enacts this article that shall be enforceable within the municipality's municipal boundaries and extraterritorial jurisdiction. This article and provisions herewith shall be included in the Weslaco Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare is of the utmost concern, the City of Weslaco shall be authorized to enforce, through its city attorney, this article as may be allowed by law herein. 
(Ord. No. 2013-27, § I, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 134-296. - Definition(s). 
    Vulnerable road user for purposes of this article shall mean: 
(1)  A pedestrian, including a runner, physically disabled person, community or school volunteers, child, skater, highway construction or maintenance worker, tow truck operator, utility worker, law enforcement personnel acting in furtherance of the color of law, worker with legitimate business on or near the road or right of way, or stranded or detained motorist or passenger; 
(2)  A person on horseback; and 
(3)  A person operating equipment other than a motor vehicle, including, but not limited to: a bicycle, moped, motor-driven cycle, or motor-assisted scooter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-27, § I, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 134-297. - Restrictions on operating a motor vehicle near vulnerable road users. 
(a)  An operator of a motor vehicle passing or approaching a vulnerable road user operating on a roadway, street, or alley shall: 
(1)  Vacate the lane in which the vulnerable road user is located if the highway or street has two or more marked lanes running in the same direction; and 
(2)  Pass the vulnerable road user at a safe distance and speed. 
(b)  For the purposes of subsection 134-297(a), when road or travel conditions allow, a safe distance is not less than: 
(1)  Three feet if the operator's vehicle is a passenger car or light truck; 
(2)  Six feet if the operator's vehicle is a truck, other than a light truck, or a commercial motor vehicle as defined by Texas Transportation Code Section 522.003. 
(c)  An operator of a motor vehicle that is making a left turn at an intersection, including an intersection with an alley or private road or driveway, shall yield the right of way to a vulnerable road user who is approaching from the opposite direction and is in intersection, or is in such proximity to the intersection as to be an immediate hazard. 
(d)  An operator of a motor vehicle may not overtake a vulnerable road user traveling in the same direction and subsequently make a right hand turn in front of the vulnerable road user unless the operator is safely clear of the vulnerable road user, taking into account the speed at which the vulnerable road user is traveling and the braking requirements of the motor vehicle making the right hand turn. 
(e)  An operator of a motor vehicle may not maneuver the vehicle in a manner that: 
(1)  Is intended to cause intimidation or harassment to a vulnerable road user; or 
(2)  Threatens a vulnerable road user. 
(f)  An operator of a motor vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any vulnerable road user on a roadway or in an intersection or roadways. 
(2013-27, § I, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 134-298. - Penalties; restitution. 
(a)  All penalties for violators of this ordinance shall be subject to a Class C misdemeanor with a fine between $50.00 and $200.00. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in Court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(b)  Should a violation proximately result in property or other harm, restitution may be ordered. 
(c)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this article if at the time of the offense; the vulnerable road user was acting in violation of law. 
(2013-27, § I, 10-15-2013) 
Chapter 138 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference- Authority of city to own and operate sewer systems and other utilities, Art. II, § 10 (see also Art. II, § 22(5)); power of city to prohibit pollution of watersheds, Art. II, § 22(1); authority of city to inspect sewer connections, Art. II, § 22(17). 
State Law reference- Municipal utility systems, general powers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 402.001 et seq.; water systems in home-rule municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 402.017; municipal jurisdiction over water and sewer utility rates, operations and services, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 13.042(a). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 138-1. - Rules and regulations of water department. 
    The water department, under the direction of the city manager, is hereby authorized and directed to establish such rules, regulations and conditions for the furnishing of water to customers as in its judgment shall be proper. 
(Code 1969, § 29-1; Ord. No. 67-9, § 3, 6-27-1967; Ord. No. 77-16, § 3, 8-16-1977) 
Sec. 138-2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 138-3. - Conditions for furnishing water outside city limits. 
    Persons who desire to purchase water, supplied through the water system of the city, for use on property lying outside the corporate limits of the city, may do so under the following conditions: 
(1)  Such persons shall pay all the expenses of laying water lines connecting such property with existing facilities of the city, at a point designated by the city engineer. 
(2)  Should such area be later taken into the city, no compensation shall be paid to the owners of such lines. 
(3)  The city shall not furnish water to any person outside the city unless the water lines outside the city are installed in accordance with the plumbing code of the city and maintained in a manner which keeps them from becoming a health hazard. 
(4)  The city reserves the right at any time to refuse water service to persons outside the city when there is a shortage of water for use inside the city, or for any violation of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 29-3; Ord. No. 295, § 1, 12-3-1957) 
Sec. 138-4. - Permit required for water connection. 
    No connection shall be made to the city's water system unless a permit therefor has been issued by the water department. Written application for such permit shall be made in all cases by the applicant and shall specify the street and number where the water service is desired. Such application must state fully and truly all purposes for which water is desired, and no different or additional use will be allowed, except upon application to and by consent of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-4; Ord. No. 79, rule 20, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-5. - Certificate of plumbing inspector prerequisite to water connection. 
    The public facilities department shall not make connections or allow water to be turned on in any new connection, either within the city or outside of the city limits, where water is furnished through the city mains, until it has received from the plumbing inspector a certificate stating that the plumbing on such premises complies with the city's plumbing requirements. 
(Code 1969, § 29-5; Ord. No. 147, 10-7-1947) 
Sec. 138-6. - Water connections to be made by city agents. 
    No person shall be authorized to tap or make any connection with the main or distributing pipes of the waterworks without the consent of the public utilities department. 
(Code 1969, § 29-6; Ord. No. 79, rule 10, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-7. - Water meters. 
    All water furnished by the city shall be measured by meters. Such meters shall be the property of the city water department. 
(Code 1969, § 29-7; Ord. No. 79, rule 19, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-8. - Reserved. 
Sec. 138-9. - Separate water connection and meter required for each residence or building. 
    Each separate residence or building in the city shall require a separate water connection and meter, and no two residences or buildings shall be allowed the use of water through the same meter. 
(Code 1969, § 29-9; Ord. No. 79, rule 11, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-10. - Special permit required for water user to supply water to another. 
    No water user will be allowed to supply water to others, except by special permit from the public facilities department. If any water user is found supplying water to another without special permission, the supply to such water user shall be stopped immediately. 
(Code 1969, § 29-10; Ord. No. 79, rule 16, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-11. - When sewer connection required. 
(a)  Every owner of a lot where a building or part of a building is occupied by people for any purpose, any part of the day or night, situated on any city block where a public sewer is laid and maintained and is adjacent to or abuts any part of such lot, shall maintain within such building or part of a building used, or upon the premises where the same is situated, a water closet or closets and have the same connected with the sewer. The work done in connection therewith and all materials used shall comply strictly with the requirements of the plumbing code. 
(b)  The city is hereby authorized, pursuant to V.T.C.A., Water Code § 17.934, to provide a sanitary sewer system to property owners within the corporate limits of the city and within the extraterritorial jurisdiction thereof. The city also is authorized to require all property owners having said sewer service adjacent or abutting their property to connect to the sewer system. All required connections shall be completed within 90 days after the city sewer service is available. Also, all existing on-site wastewater systems shall be eliminated, in accordance to state law, upon connection to the city sewer system. The city is also authorized to charge the property owner for the sewer service even if the property owner fails to connect said service within the 90-day period. 
(Code 1969, § 29-11; Ord. No. 161, § 36, 1-4-1949; Ord. No. 95-16, § 2, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 2004-15, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 138-12. - Privies prohibited; septic tanks where sewer connection not required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or use, in connection with any residence or business, a dry closet or pit toilet for the disposition of domestic sewage within the city. 
(b)  Persons occupying premises not so situated as to require a sewer connection under section 138-11 are hereby required to construct and connect a private sewage system to a septic tank and drainline system of a capacity and design adequate to serve the number of persons occupying the premises. The plans and specifications for such system shall be approved by the city code enforcement department as a prerequisite to the granting of a building permit for the construction of any business or residential structure. 
(Code 1969, § 29-12; Ord. No. 269, §§ 1, 2, 5-1-1956) 
Sec. 138-13. - Ownership and maintenance of water service pipe. 
    The water service pipe from the main, including the connection, lead pipe to curb, stopcock, and corporation stop, is the property of the owner of the premises, all of which, and all pipe fixtures connected therewith, must be kept in good repair, and the occupant of the premises must prevent all unnecessary waste of water. 
(Code 1969, § 29-15; Ord. No. 79, rule 12, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-14. - Steam boilers not to be supplied from service pipes. 
    Feed pumps supplying water to steam boilers shall not be permitted to take water directly from the service pipes. Water for steam boilers must be drawn from an open receptacle into which the water has been previously discharged. 
(Code 1969, § 29-16; Ord. No. 79, rule 13, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-15. - Protection of water meters connected with steam boilers; responsibility for damage. 
    Where a steam boiler is supplied by the city water system, the plumbing shall be constructed in such manner as will prevent the hot water produced by the boiler from backing into the water meter. The owner of the premises will be held responsible for all damages to meters resulting from hot water backing up into them. 
(Code 1969, § 29-17; Ord. No. 79, rule 14, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-16. - Connections. 
    All water connections shall be provided with a corporation stop with a lead goose neck attached from the main, and with lead or copper service pipe to the meter, which shall be provided with a corporation stop. 
(Code 1969, § 29-18; Ord. No. 79, rule 15, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-17. - Location of meters and corporation stops. 
    All water meters and corporation stops shall be placed in a plastic box, the cover of which shall have the word "Water" on it. 
(Code 1969, § 29-19; Ord. No. 79, rule 15, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-18. - Right of entry to premises supplied with city water. 
    The public facilities department shall have free access at all reasonable hours of the day to all parts of any premises to which water is supplied by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-20; Ord. No. 79, rule 17, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-19. - Right of fire department to use water fixtures. 
    In case of fire, the fire department shall have the right to use any hydrant, hose, pipe, or other fixture supplied wholly or in part for any service pipe used for fire protection. 
(Code 1969, § 29-21; Ord. No. 79, rule 18, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-20. - Quantity or pressure of water not guaranteed by city. 
    Consumers of city water are not guaranteed a specific quantity or pressure of water for any purpose whatever, and no officer, agent, or employee of the city shall have the authority at any time to connect or agree, for or on behalf of the city, to furnish or guarantee any particular pressure of water. It is understood in every case that the person making connection with the waterworks system does so with the understanding that the city is simply to furnish connection with its water system, and is in no case to be held to any liability for failure or refusal to furnish water, or any particular amount or pressure of water. 
(Code 1969, § 29-22; Ord. No. 79, rule 24, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-21. - Turning water on after disconnection by city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to turn the water on to any premises from which the supply has been turned off by authority of the city, without first having obtained authorization to do so from the water department. 
(Code 1969, § 29-23; Ord. No. 79, rule 4, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-22. - Water from hydrants not to run on streets or sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit the water from any hydrant situated upon premises owned or controlled by such person to run upon any sidewalk or street of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-24; Ord. No. 79, rule 1, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-23. - Wastewater not to be discharged on street or public ground. 
    No person shall cause or allow to be discharged from his premises the water from any fountain or sink upon the surface or any part of any street or public ground within the city. The public facilities department may, when it is necessary, notify any person not to allow water from any fountain or sink on his premises to be discharged in violation of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 29-25; Ord. No. 79, rule 9, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-24. - Injuring or defacing waterworks property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully injure, deface or destroy any reservoir, machinery, pipe, hydrant or other fixture or property belonging to the waterworks system of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-26; Ord. No. 79, rule 2, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-25. - Opening or interfering with fire hydrants. 
    Every hydrant placed by the water department for the purpose of extinguishing fires is hereby declared to be a public hydrant, and no person other than members of the fire department, the health department, and those authorized by the city commission shall open any such hydrant, draw or attempt to draw water from the same, or in any manner interfere with such a hydrant. 
(Code 1969, § 29-27; Ord. No. 79, rule 3, 6-21-1932) 
Sec. 138-26. - Obstructing access to fire hydrants. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct the vehicles' access to any hydrant referred to in section 138-25, by means of any lumber, brick, building material or other articles, or by any hindrance whatsoever. 
(Code 1969, § 29-28; Ord. No. 79, rule 5, 6-21-1932) 
Secs. 138-27-138-57. - Reserved.

Sec. 138-60. - Septic tank waste; procedures and fee. 
    The city may accept septic tank waste from businesses and residences of the city at the wastewater treatment plant. 
(1)  The waste shall not be combined with waste from other sources. 
(2)  Waste shall be transported by registered hauler only. 
(3)  Manifests shall be properly completed and submitted. 
(4)  The fee shall be $35.00 per load. 
(5)  Waste shall be hauled to the city wastewater treatment plant Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
(6)  Acceptance of the waste is contingent upon the plant being able to handle the load. The city shall not be obligated to accept any waste deemed a burden to the operation of the plant. 
(7)  The wastewater treatment plant will not accept grease trap or other toxic materials. 
(8)  The wastewater treatment plant reserves the right to test every load brought in. 
(Code 1969, § 29-43.1; Ord. No. 94-07, 3-15-1994) 
Sec. 138-61. - Reserved. 
Sec. 138-62. - Meter deposit required. 
    Each applicant for city water service shall be required to make a meter deposit for the purpose of guaranteeing the payment of the charges prescribed by this article. For residential water users, the amount of the meter deposit shall be two times the minimum bill. For commercial and larger users of water, the meter deposit shall be an amount large enough to sufficiently protect the water department against any loss in case the monthly bill is not paid. 
(Code 1969, § 29-45; Ord. No. 79, rule 21, 6-21-1932; Ord. No. 77-16, § 6, 8-16-1977) 
Sec. 138-63. - Payment due date; penalty for late payment. 
(a)  All bills under any schedule shall be due and payable on the due date of such bill, which shall be 15 days from the date of such a bill. If said bill is not paid by the due date, a penalty of ten percent shall be added to the original amount due and shall be remitted by the customer in addition to the original amount billed. Should any account, including those described in subsection (b) of this section, remain unpaid for seven days past the due date, the customer's account shall be considered delinquent and service terminated. When service is terminated for failure to pay utility bills, a charge of $10.00 shall be made for reconnecting. 
(b)  The following residential accounts are exempt from the ten percent penalty provision only: 
(1)  Elderly persons 65 years of age or older who have an account with the city water department and have filed with that department an approval application showing their age and certifying that the service address is in fact their homestead. 
(2)  Elderly persons 65 years of age or older who have an account with the city water department where the service address is the same as property appearing on the 65 and over list produced by the county appraisal district. 
(Code 1969, § 29-46; Ord. No. 79, rule 23, 6-21-1932; Ord. No. 144, § 4, 6-3-1947; Ord. No. 145, § 1, 8-5-1947; Ord. No. 77-16, § 2, 8-16-1977; Ord. No. 78-13, 6-13-1978; Ord. No. 87-10, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 93-35, § 1, 10-5-1993) 
Sec. 138-64. - Delinquent accounts; termination of service; reconnection; NSF charge. 
    Should any account remain unpaid for seven days past the due date, the customer's account shall be considered delinquent and service terminated. When service is terminated for failure to pay utility bills, a charge of $10.00 shall be made for reconnecting. After a consumer's service has been disconnected, no one shall make a reconnection or obtain any water by any manner from the disconnected place, except authorized employees of the water department. A charge of $15.00 shall be made for all checks that are returned NSF on payments made for water and sewer accounts. 
(Code 1969, § 29-47; Ord. No. 79, rule 23, 6-21-1932; Ord. No. 145, § 1, 8-5-1947; Ord. No. 67-9, § 2, 6-27-1967; Ord. No. 77-16, § 2, 6-27-1967; Ord. No. 78-13, 6-13-1978; Ord. No. 93-35, §§ 2, 3, 10-5-1993) 
Sec. 138-65. - Sewer revenues. 
    All monies collected by the water department for sewer service shall be placed in a separate fund known as the sewer fund of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-48; Ord. No. 144, § 4, 6-3-1947) 
Secs. 138-66-138-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER CONSERVATION AND EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public water suppliers required by rule to develop drought contingency plans, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 11.1272; drought contingency plans for municipal uses by public water suppliers, 30 Tex. Admin. Code § 288.20. 

Sec. 138-89. - Plan adopted; penalty for violation of mandatory use restrictions. 
(a)  The city's Water Conservation and Emergency Water Demand Management Plan, attached to the ordinance from which this chapter is derived and available on file at the office of the city secretary, and by reference made a part thereof for all purposes, is hereby adopted as the official policy of the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of the mandatory water use restrictions which have been formally initiated by the city and contained in the Water Conservation and Emergency Water Demand Management Plan, as adopted herein, shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed the sum of $500.00 for each offense, and each and every day any such violation shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 29-61; Ord. No. 96-11, §§ 1, 4, 5-7-1996) 
Sec. 138-90. - Wholesale customers. 
    The City of Weslaco, in the event this plan is activated, shall distribute water to all current and future wholesale providers in accordance with this plan. Existing customers shall be requested to reduce demand as described below, and are subject to the same use prohibitions listed above. 
    Upon activation of any stage of this plan, wholesale customers shall be directly notified within 24 hours. Wholesalers are required to notify their customers within seven days of the activation of any stage of this plan. All relevant portions of this plan are effective at the end of this seven-day period. 
    The notification to wholesale customers shall include the following language: "The City reserves the right, under Section 11.039(b)(2) of the Texas Water Code, to reduce the amount of water supplied to wholesale customers in accordance with the goals established under the Drought and Emergency Contingency Plan. Wholesale suppliers are encouraged to adopt this or a similar plan to achieve the necessary demand reductions within their system that will accomplish the goals of the City of Weslaco Drought Contingency Plan. Any reduction in water supplied to wholesale customers shall be limited to those stated in the targets for each stage (e.g. Stage 1, 2% reduction from previous thirty day water consumption), unless otherwise determined by the City Manager, or his/her designee, as described in the complete plan." 
(Ord. No. 2008-27, § I(3.13), 9-25-2008) 
Secs. 138-91-138-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LAWN IRRIGATION
